context: In order to reduce the number of items damaged while in transit to customers, packaging consultants recommended that the TrueSave mail-order company increase the amount of packing material so as to fill any empty spaces in its cartons. Accordingly, TrueSave officials instructed the company's packers to use more packing material than before, and the packers zealously acted on these instructions and used as much as they could. Nevertheless, customer reports of damaged items rose somewhat.
question: How does the fact that TrueSave has lost some of its regular customers as a result of the high number of damaged items they received not help to explain why acting on the consultants' recommendation failed to achieve its goal?
answers: The employees stuck as much packing material as the could get into the packages, implying they compressed it to get more into the package.
There were no reports by customers about how easy or hard it was to unpack their items. There were just reports of damage.
There was no mention on the costs of using more material so we can not conclude that it cost more.
There was no mention of customers leaving the company. Only that they reported damage.
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most helps to explain why acting on the consultants' recommendation failed to achieve its goal?
main_answers: TrueSave has lost some of its regular customers as a result of the high number of damaged items they received.
The amount of packing material used in a carton does not significantly influence the ease with which a customer can unpack the package.
The change in packing policy led to an increase in expenditure on packing material and labor.
When packing material is compressed too densely, it loses some of its capacity to absorb shock.
others.target_option: TrueSave has lost some of its regular customers as a result of the high number of damaged items they received.

context: Publishers, like all private businesses, have always been concerned about profitability. But, while it used to be at least possible to get a book published that was unlikely to be popular, and hence unlikely to be a moneymaker, profitability is now the sole criterion. Thus, no matter how much literary merit a book possesses, it will not be published in today' s market if it looks like it will not be popular.

Calcium carbonate can neutralize stomach acid, but at the same time, stimulate the production of gastrin, which is a hormone that triggers the making of acid.
The author does not argue that it is harder to get any book published today, only those that are unlikely to be popular.
The author does not argue that no books of literary merit can be published in today's market.
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following sentences most accurately expresses the main conclusion of the argument?
main_answers: Good books are published now only if they are also likely to be popular.
Unpopular books are not likely to make money for the publisher.
Books of literary merit cannot be published in today's market.
It is harder to get a book published today than it once was.
others.target_option: It is harder to get a book published today than it once was.

context: Recent investigations of earthquakes have turned up a previously unknown type of seismic shock, known as a displacement pulse, which is believed to be present in all earthquakes. Alarmingly, high-rise buildings are especially vulnerable to displacement pulses, according to computer models. Yet examination of high-rises within cities damaged by recent powerful earthquakes indicates little significant damage to these structures.
question: Explain why the fact that computer models have been very successful in predicting the effects of other types of seismic shock does not contribute to a resolution of the apparent paradox?
answers: Even if there was confirmation that they accompanied all earthquakes instead of just being believed to, that would only contribute to the assumption that these high-rises should have had more damage.
The passage solely examines high-rises within cities damaged by recent powerful earthquakes, not low and medium intensity earthquakes,

If scientific predictions from computer models often fail when actually tested, this would mean that the prediction that high-rise buildings are especially vulnerable to displacement pulses is simply incorrect upon actual examination.
Being successful at predicting other types of seismic shocks does not imply being successful at predicting displacement pulses.
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, contributes to a resolution of the apparent paradox?
main_answers: Computer models have been very successful in predicting the effects of other types of seismic shock.
Scientific predictions based on computer models often fail when tested in the field.
The displacement pulses made by low- and medium-intensity earthquakes are much less powerful than those made by the strongest earthquakes.
While displacement pulses have only recently been discovered, they have accompanied all earthquakes that have ever occurred.
others.target_option: Computer models have been very successful in predicting the effects of other types of seismic shock.

context: Although most people know what their bad habits are and want to rid themselves of them, a majority of these people find it very difficult to do so. This is because cessation of habitual behavior is immediately and vividly painful, while whatever benefit is to be gained by the absence of the habit is perceived only dimly because it is remote.
question: Why does the information not strongly support the statement that the people who are successful at ending their bad habits are those who have succeeded in the past at modifying their behavior?
answers: Modifying behavior is not quite the same as completely ending a bad behavioral characteristic.
Someone who is unaware of their own bad habits is not likely to want to change them.
Imagining the current pain continuing into the future is defeatism, which is the opposite of motivation.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The information above most strongly supports the statement that the people who are most successful at ending their bad habits are those who
main_answers: have succeeded in the past at modifying their behavior
can vividly imagine remote but attainable benefit
can vividly imagine their present pain being felt in the future
are relatively unaware of their own behavioral characteristics
others.target_option: have succeeded in the past at modifying their behavior

context: A major art theft from a museum was remarkable in that the pieces stolen clearly had been carefully selected. The criterion for selection, however, clearly had not been greatest estimated market value. It follows that the theft was specifically carried out to suit the taste of some individual collector for whose private collection the pieces were destined.
question: Why does the argument not tacitly appeal to the principle that any art theft committed at the direction of a single individual results in a pattern of works taken and works left alone that defies rational analysis?
answers: The passage is not suggesting that the thief was irrational, but that he or she was motivated by something other than pure market value.
The passage is concerned with the motivation of the theft and not the damage to the collection of art.
The husband is not seeking a penalty for an action, but rather violating an agreement and the ability to pay restitution to the husband by the wife is not stated.
The husband agreed to no seek compensation and then broke the agreement, which the ethicist sees as morally wrong.
label: A

others.main_question: The argument tacitly appeals to which one of the following principles?
main_answers: Any art theft committed at the direction of a single individual results in a pattern of works taken and works left alone that defies rational analysis.
The pattern of works taken and works left alone in an art theft can be particularly damaging to the integrity of the remaining collection.
The pattern of works taken and works left alone can sometimes distinguish one type of art theft from another.
Art thefts committed with no preexisting plan for the disposition of the stolen works do not always involve theft of the most valuable pieces only.
others.target_option: Any art theft committed at the direction of a single individual results in a pattern of works taken and works left alone that defies rational analysis.

context: Cognitive scientist: Using the pioneering work of comparative psychologist Gordon Gallup as a model, several studies have investigated animals' capacity for mirror self-recognition (MSR). Most animals exposed to a mirror respond only with social behavior, such as aggression. However, in the case of the great apes, repeated exposure to mirrors leads to self-directed behaviors, such as exploring the inside of the mouth, suggesting that these animals recognize the reflection as an image of self. The implication of these studies is that the great apes have a capacity for self-awareness unique among nonhuman species.
question: Why is it valid to conclude that the cognitive scientist makes the assumption that if an animal does not have the capacity for MSR, it does not have the capacity for self-awareness in the argument?
answers: This is the correct answer because the cognitive scientist draws his conclusion about animal self-awareness exclusively from the MSR experiment.
This is false because great apes, like all animals, initially show social behavior but eventually show self-directed behavior thus demonstrating their self-awareness.

This is not true because the argument explicitly states that of all animals only the great apes initially display social behavior but eventually learn to recognize themselves in the mirror and begin to indulge in self-directed behavior.
The cognitive scientist does not even consider such a possibility.
label: A

others.main_question: The cognitive scientist makes which of the following assumptions in the argument above?
main_answers: If an animal does not have the capacity for MSR, it does not have the capacity for self-awareness.
When exposed to a mirror, all animals display either social behavior or self-directed behavior.
Animals that do not exhibit MSR may demonstrate a capacity for self-awareness in other ways.
If a researcher exposes an animal to a mirror and that animal exhibits social behavior, that animal is incapable of being self-aware.
others.target_option: If an animal does not have the capacity for MSR, it does not have the capacity for self-awareness.

context: Statistics from the National Booksellers Association indicate that during the last five years most bookstores have started to experience declining revenues from the sale of fiction, despite national campaigns to encourage people to read more fiction. Ttherefore, these reading campaigns have been largely unsuccessful.
question: Explain why the fact that the National Booksellers Association statistics do not include profits from selling novels by mail to overseas customers does not seriously weaken the argument.
answers: The statement talks about a national campaign that would not include overseas customers.
The newly rich consumers will not know about the watches because they were not being advertised in publications that they read when they were not wealthy.
Even if the customers of Brand X's watches didn't see the magazines, they would still see the billboards.
This statement does not contain information on how much fiction people are reading, onlly that more profit is coming from other areas.
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following statements, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
main_answers: The National Booksellers Association statistics do not include profits from selling novels by mail to overseas customers.
During the last five years the most profitable items in bookstores have been newspapers and periodicals rather than novels.

Due to the poor economic conditions that have prevailed during the last five years, most libraries report substantial increases in the number of patrons seeking books on changing careers and starting new businesses.
Mail order book clubs have enjoyed substantial growth in fiction sales throughout the last five years.
others.target_option: The National Booksellers Association statistics do not include profits from selling novels by mail to overseas customers.

context: Trisha: Today' s family is declining in its ability to carry out its functions of child-rearing and providing stability for adult life. There must be a return to the traditional values of commitment and responsibility. Jerod: We ought to leave what is good enough alone. question: What is the source of the disagreement between Trisha and Jerod regarding whether the institution of the family is adequate as it is?
answers: The argument does not mention value to the people
Trisha is arguing that things were better with traditional families and Jerod is arguing that they are good now, the argument is about the quality of the relationship now.
Both Trisha and Jerod agree that families are no longer traditional, this is not what the argument is about.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Trisha and Jerod disagree over whether the institution of the family is
main_answers: valued by most people
changing over time
adequate as it is
no longer traditional
others.target_option: adequate as it is

context: According to experts on shopping behavior, more shoppers would shop at Jerrod' s department store if they were offered the convenience of shopping carts. answers: This would have no bearing on the profits, I would hope that this is true but the openness of the store will not affect profits.
This would make sense because the customer would have a larger place to put items thus making it easier for them top justify buying more without taking multiple trips.
This would contradict the argument that is trying to be made, if you have to pay more employees than the profit will go down.
None of the above choices
label: A

a customer with a shopping cart buys more, on average, than a customer without a cart
stores that make shopping carts available to customers usually have to hire people to retrieve them from parking areas

others.target_option: the layout of Jerrod's is open enough to accommodate shopping carts comfortably

question: What is the reasoning behind the conclusion that a customer with a shopping cart buys more, on average, than a customer without a cart logically completing the argument?
answers: This would make sense because the customer would have a larger place to put items thus making it easier for them top justify buying more without taking multiple trips.
This would have no bearing on the profits, I would hope that this is true but the openness of the store will not affect profits.
This would contradict the argument that is trying to be made, if you have to pay more employees than the profit will go down.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which of the following most logically completes the argument?
main_answers: the layout of Jerrod's is open enough to accommodate shopping carts comfortably
a customer with a shopping cart buys more, on average, than a customer without a cart
stores that make shopping carts available to customers usually have to hire people to retrieve them from parking areas
there are some potential customers who would not be enticed to shop at Jerrod's by the availability of shopping carts
others.target_option: a customer with a shopping cart buys more, on average, than a customer without a cart

context: During its caterpillar stage, the leopard magpie moth feeds on a plant called the Natal grass cycad and by so doing laces its body with macrozamin, a toxin that makes the moth highly unpalatable to would-be predators. Since the Natal grass cycad is now endangered and facing extinction, the leopard magpie moth is also in danger of extinction.
question: Which of the following reasoning justifies that the argument does not require the assumption that none of the potential predators of the leopard magpie moth have developed a tolerance to macrozamin?
answers: Since potential predators find the leopard magpie moth unpalatable, they are not able to consume them and build a tolerance.
Potential predators find macrozamin unpalatable whether they can see it or not.
If  the leopard magpie moth had other means of making itself unpalatable, there'd be no relation between either going extinct.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the argument?
main_answers: Potential predators of the leopard magpie moth cannot determine from appearance alone whether a moth's body is laced with macrozamin.
The leopard magpie moth does not have the speed or the agility to escape from any of its potential predators.
None of the potential predators of the leopard magpie moth have developed a tolerance to macrozamin.
Feeding on the Natal grass cycad is the only means by which the leopard magpie moth can make itself highly unpalatable to predators.
others.target_option: None of the potential predators of the leopard magpie moth have developed a tolerance to macrozamin.

context: A company that imports and sells collectibles sought to have some of its collectible figurines classified as toys, which are subject to lower import tariffs than collectibles. The company argued that the figurines amuse customers, just as toys do. However, the government agency responsible for tariffs rejected the company' s request on the grounds that the figurines are marketed as collector' s items rather than toys.
question: Explain why the principle that when importing products, a company should seek the tariff classification that results in the lowest tariffs does not help to justify the government agency's decision.
answers: This seems like it is what the company wants to do, it does not help the government agency's decision.
If the classification is based off how an item is marketed than this would justify the actions of the government.
The question about prices does not help the government agency with their decision.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following principles, if valid, most helps to justify the government agency's decision?
main_answers: The tariff classification of an item should depend primarily on how the item is marketed.
Objects that are developed primarily to provide amusement should be subject to lower tariffs than other objects.
When importing products, a company should seek the tariff classification that results in the lowest tariffs.
A company should market its products as collectibles rather than toys if doing so enables it to sell them for higher prices.
others.target_option: When importing products, a company should seek the tariff classification that results in the lowest tariffs.

context: Reasonable people adapt themselves to the world; unreasonable people persist in trying to adapt the world to themselves. Ttherefore, all progress depends on unreasonable people.
question: Explain why it is not necessary to conclude that reasonable people and unreasonable people are incompatible in order for the statement to be true?
answers: Even if some unreasonable people are unable to bring about progress, it remains true that other unreasonable people are able to bring about progress.
Reasonable people and unreasonable people may or may not be compatible, it is unknow.
If unreasonable people are the only means of progress, than a population of only reasonable people would have no progress.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: If all of the statements in the passage above are true, which one of the following statements must also be true?
main_answers: Reasonable people and unreasonable people are incompatible.
If there are only reasonable people, there cannot be progress.
Some unreasonable people are unable to bring about progress.
If there are unreasonable people, there will be progress.
others.target_option: Reasonable people and unreasonable people are incompatible.

context: Humans are supposedly rational: in other words, they have a capacity for well-considered thinking and behavior. This is supposedly the difference that makes them superior to other animals. But humans knowingly pollute the world' s precious air and water and, through bad farming practices, deplete the soil that feeds them. Thus, humans are not rational after all, so it is absurd to regard them as superior to other animals.
question: Why is the reasoning not considered to be invalid for presuming, without evidence, that humans are no worse than other animals?
answers: The passage references one way in which humans act irrationally, however the awareness of this irrationality has no bearing on human superiority in relation to other animals.
The author focuses narrowly on one human activity and does not distinguish areas where humans can act in a superior manner.
The author notes that humans act irrationally at times and this does not make them superior to other animals thus leading to the conclusion that humans are worse than other animals.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: The reasoning above is flawed in that it
main_answers: neglects to show that the irrational acts perpetrated by humans are not also perpetrated by other animals
presumes, without offering justification, that humans are no worse than other animals
fails to recognize that humans may possess a capacity without displaying it in a given activity
takes for granted that humans are aware that their acts are irrational
others.target_option: presumes, without offering justification, that humans are no worse than other animals

context: Heavy rains during Centralia' s corn planting season prevented some farmers there from planting corn. It is now the planting season for soybeans, another of Centralia' s principal crops, and those fields originally intended for corn are dry enough for planting. Nonetheless, even though soybean prices are unusually high at present, the farmers will leave most of these fields empty rather than plant them with soybeans, since__.
question: Why does the fact that some Centralian farmers anticipate serious financial losses due to the extremely wet spring planting season not logically complete the passage?
answers: Farmers would have to avoid planting soybeans in the fields intended for corn if the applied chemicals would prevent a healthy soybean harvest.
If Centralian farmers grow both corn and soybeans, they would want to plant soybeans to recover some of the lost profit from missing the corn season.
The planting season for corn was missed due to extensive rain so the increased price of corn does not impact the farmers' current decision to leave the field empty.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following most logically completes the passage below?
main_answers: some Centralian farmers anticipate serious financial losses due to the extremely wet spring planting season
many Centralian farmers grow both corn and soybeans
the extensive rains have led to an increase in the price of corn
chemicals that were used to prepare the fields for corn planting would stunt the growth of soybeans
others.target_option: some Centralian farmers anticipate serious financial losses due to the extremely wet spring planting season

context: Professor: A guest speaker recently delivered a talk entitled "The Functions of Democratic Governments" to a Political Ideologies class at this university. The talk was carefully researched and theoretical in nature. But two students who disagreed with the theory hurled vicious taunts at the speaker. Several others applauded their attempt to humiliate the speaker. This incident shows that universities these days do not foster fair-minded and tolerant intellectual debate.
question: What is the rationale for why the professor's reasoning is flawed for drawing a general conclusion based on too small a sample?
answers: The passage does not show intolerance of the students' views and merely gives the reader information as to what happened before the author states their viewpoint and conclusion.
There is no indication that the phases of the moon cause a change in temperature but rather align with the changes of seasons and temperatures that happen naturally.
Planting after the first frost will avoid the dangers of frost and likely cause more plants to survive.
The conclusion is based upon only one incident and therefore one sample which is far too little information.
label: D

others.main_question: The professor's reasoning is flawed in that it
main_answers: draws a general conclusion based on too small a sample
is inconsistent in advocating tolerance while showing intolerance of the dissenting students' views
draws a conclusion based on the professor's own opinion rather than on that of the majority of the students present at the talk
relies primarily on an emotional appeal
others.target_option: draws a general conclusion based on too small a sample

context: Nutritionist: The food pyramid was amended to provide the public with a healthier nutrition plan to combat the obesity epidemic. The base of the previous food pyramid -- the grains group -- advised people to eat six-to-eleven servings of pasta and bread per day. In contrast, the updated pictorial nutrition guide shows a plate, and it reduces the percentage of dietary intake of grains and replaces the difference with lean proteins and vegetables. The updated guide has been wildly successful, as citizens have lost a significant amount of weight.
question: Why does the fact that citizens have started to exercise more since the publication of the updated food guide not strengthen the nutritionist's conclusion?
answers: Heart disease related to pasta and bread does not affect whether people would lose weight eating more vegetables and protein.
There is no evidence that the makeup of how the pyramid is displayed would have any effect on how people follow it.
Exercising more would cause weight loss and would be a factor rather than the change in diet alone..

If eating more proteins and vegetables leads to weight loss then changing the recommendation to include larger portions of these types of foods supports the idea that it is the reason people lost weight under the new food pyramid.
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the nutritionist's conclusion?
main_answers: Since the publication of the updated food guide, citizens have started to exercise more.
Eating more lean proteins and vegetables contributes to weight loss.
Eating six-to-eleven servings of pasta and bread increased citizens' risk of heart disease.
The old food pyramid used horizontal layers, while the updated guide uses vertical layers.
others.target_option: Since the publication of the updated food guide, citizens have started to exercise more.

context: Despite the best efforts of astronomers, no one has yet succeeded in exchanging messages with intelligent life on other planets or in other solar systems. In fact, no one has even managed to prove that any kind of extraterrestrial life exists. Thus, there is clearly no intelligent life anywhere but on Earth.
question: Why is the argument's reasoning not considered to be invalid due to its reliance on the ambiguity of the term "life"?
answers: The passage makes no suggestion about where the classical records were recorded.
The argument is founded on the absence of evidence of ANY life, with no definition of that concept being given.
The argument is concerned only with the existence of life (intelligent or otherwise) beyond the Earth, not on the existence of intelligence per se.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: The argument's reasoning is flawed because the argument
main_answers: relies on a weak analogy rather than on evidence to draw a conclusion
confuses an absence of evidence for a hypothesis with the existence of evidence against the hypothesis
makes an inference that relies on the vagueness of the term "life"
fails to consider that there might be extraterrestrial forms of intelligence that are not living beings
others.target_option: makes an inference that relies on the vagueness of the term "life"

answers: Bringing up the inability to play chess does not contribute to the argument about whether playing chess requires thinking or not.
This option might be an underlying assumption of the argument of the passage.
The official implies previously that cabin secretaries should only be for citizens so foreign citizens naturally should not be undersecretaries.
The official is talking about what roles a foreign citizen is fit for not about any legal processes for citizenship.
label: A

context: Of 2, 500 people who survived a first heart attack, those who did not smoke had their first heart attack at a median age of 62. However, of those 2, 500, people who smoked two packs of cigarettes a day had their first heart attack at a median age of 51. question: Why is the conclusion not considered to be valid even if the information includes the earliest age at which a person who smoked two packs a day had his or her first heart attack?
answers: Alberto doesn't list any musical experts when he is making his argument.

He suggests that Mozart himself might not have heard the music as he intended it to be played, because it was common to add some interpretation to the music as it was being played.
The ages given are an average and does not mean that someone will have that heart attack at that earliest age given. It could happen even earlier.

context: During the recent economic downturn, banks contributed to the decline by loaning less money. Prior to the downturn, regulatory standards for loanmaking by banks were tightened. Clearly, ttherefore, banks will lend more money if those standards are relaxed.
question: What evidence is there to suggest that the reason for tightening the regulatory standards was not arbitrary?
answers: If the reasons for tightening were arbitrary, then there is no reason to believe that the regulatory standards has any effect on the banks choosing to loan less or more money in the first place.
If the downturn caused a significant decrease in the total money on deposit, then the banks would not have similar amounts of funds to lend even if the regulatory standards were loosened.
The passage states that during the recent economic downturn, banks loaned less money, which does not necessarily have to be a significant decrease.
Not compensating the banks entirely for the downturn does not mean that banks would willingly not want to be compensated even partially for the downturn.
label: A

others.main_question: The argument assumes that
main_answers: the reason for tightening the regulatory standards was not arbitrary
no relaxation of standards for loanmaking by banks would compensate for the effects of the downturn
no economic downturn is accompanied by a significant decrease in the amount of money loaned out by banks to individual borrowers and to businesses
the downturn did not cause a significant decrease in the total amount of money on deposit with banks which is the source of funds for banks to lend
others.target_option: the reason for tightening the regulatory standards was not arbitrary

context: Ronan rarely attended class during his first semester at law school. Some of his professors didn' t know he was in the class until the final exam. Ronan finished the year in the top 10 percent of his class and earned a spot on the school' s prestigious law review.
question: How does the fact that Ronan learns better through reading than listening, and he read the most relevant treatise on every class explain the apparent paradox?
answers: Ronan's professors skills is not relevant as Ronan did not attend their classes and as such does not explain his exam score.
Class attendance being optional or not has no bearing on Ronan's ability to pass the exam.

If Ronan were lazy he would not be able to achieve a high score on his exam which requires a great deal of effort and ability.

context: Economist: Technology now changes so rapidly that workers need periodic retraining. Such retraining can be efficient only if it allows individual companies to meet their own shortterm needs. Hence, large governmental job retraining programs are no longer a viable option in the effort to retrain workers efficiently.
question: What is the reasoning that justifies the economist's argument not requiring the assumption that no single type of retraining program is most efficient at retraining technological workers?
answers: The likeliness of workers moving should not have an effect on whether large governmental retraining programs are viable or not as those programs can be anywhere.
If the pace of technological change slowed, it would stand to reason that large programs that tend to be slower to change would be benefited more from having to adapt less.

The author argues that meeting the short-term needs of individual companies is a requirement and argues that as a result, large governmental job retraining programs don't work, therefore, it must be assumed that the government programs can't fulfill that requirement.
There is no reason to assume that large government retraining programs would be incapable of having multiple subtypes of programs within the larger structure.
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the economist's argument?
main_answers: No single type of retraining program is most efficient at retraining technological workers.
Large governmental job retraining programs do not meet the short-term needs of individual companies.
Technological workers are more likely now than in the past to move in order to find work for which they are already trained.
Large job retraining programs will be less efficient than smaller programs if the pace of technological change slows.
others.target_option: No single type of retraining program is most efficient at retraining technological workers.

context: In a vast ocean region, phosphorus levels have doubled in the past few decades due to agricultural runoff pouring out of a large river nearby. The phosphorus stimulates the growth of plankton near the ocean surface. Decaying plankton fall to the ocean floor, where bacteria devour them, consuming oxygen in the process. Due to the resulting oxygen depletion, few fish can survive in this region.
question: Explain why it is not valid to infer that the quantity of agricultural runoff pouring out of the river has doubled in the past few decades based on the information provided?
answers: The amount of runoff is directly quantified by the author and thus cannot be inferred.
Fish survivability depends on other factors, not just phosphorous level, thus their survivability cannot be assumed.
The author describes the process by which runoff turns into phosphorous and contributes to the life cycle of bacteria and thus the plankton.
The author mentions agricultural runoff as one cause of bacteria on the ocean floor not the sole cause.
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following can be properly inferred from the information above?
main_answers: The quantity of agricultural runoff pouring out of the river has doubled in the past few decades.
Before phosphorus levels doubled in the ocean region, most fish were able to survive in that region.
If agricultural runoff ceased pouring out of the river, there would be no bacteria on the ocean floor devouring decaying plankton.
The agricultural runoff pouring out of the river contributes to the growth of plankton near the ocean surface.
others.target_option: The quantity of agricultural runoff pouring out of the river has doubled in the past few decades.

context: Though sucking zinc lozenges has been promoted as a treatment for the common cold, research has revealed no consistent effect. Recently, however, a zinc gel applied nasally has been shown to greatly reduce the duration of colds. Since the gel contains zinc in the same form and concentration as the lozenges, the greater effectiveness of the gel must be due to the fact that cold viruses tend to concentrate in the nose, not the mouth.
question: Explain why the fact that experimental subjects who used the zinc gel not only had colds of shorter duration but also had less severe symptoms than did those who used a gel that did not contain zinc does not seriously weaken the argument.
answers: Whether the mechanism has been established or not does not matter when considering the results, whether the mechanism has been identified or is understood does not change the results that are being seen.
If both products have zinc but only one has other chemicals that inhibit zinc, it  is logical to assume that the product without those inhibiting chemicals would be more effective.
If people using zinc gel were less sick than people using lozenges they would likely get better faster whether they used treatment or not.
If basic nasal spray has the same effect then the result may not be from the zinc gel but from some other factor.
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
main_answers: Experimental subjects who used the zinc gel not only had colds of shorter duration but also had less severe symptoms than did those who used a gel that did not contain zinc.
Drug-company researchers experimenting with a nasal spray based on zinc have found that it has much the same effect on colds as the gel does.
To make them palatable, zinc lozenges generally contain other ingredients, such as citric acid, that can interfere with the chemical activity of zinc.
The mechanism by which zinc affects the viruses that cause the common cold has not been conclusively established.
others.target_option: Experimental subjects who used the zinc gel not only had colds of shorter duration but also had less severe symptoms than did those who used a gel that did not contain zinc.

context: Editorialist: Despite the importance it seems to have in our lives, money does not really exist. This is evident from the fact that all that would be needed to make money disappear would be a universal loss of belief in it. We witness this phenomenon on a small scale daily in the rises and falls of financial markets, whose fluctuations are often entirely independent of concrete causes and are the results of mere beliefs of investors.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that the conclusion of the editorialist's argument can be properly drawn if it is assumed that whatever is true of money is true of financial markets generally?
answers: The author does not link the existence of money to the existence of financial markets, they merely cite the variance of financial markets as evidence.
The author states that money wouldn't exist if there was a universal loss of belief in it, implying that only some people must believe in money for it to exist, not everyone.
The author doesn't state anything about mistaken beliefs being relevant to a thing's existence.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: The conclusion of the editorialist's argument can be properly drawn if which one of the following is assumed?
main_answers: Whatever is true of money is true of financial markets generally.
If everyone believes in something, then that thing exists.
Only if one can have mistaken beliefs about a thing does that thing exist, strictly speaking.
Anything that exists would continue to exist even if everyone were to stop believing in it.
others.target_option: Whatever is true of money is true of financial markets generally.

context: Durth: Increasingly, businesses use direct mail advertising instead of paying for advertising space in newspapers, in magazines, or on billboards. This practice is annoying and also immoral. Most direct mail advertisements are thrown out without ever being read, and the paper on which they are printed is wasted. If anyone else wasted this much paper, it would be considered unconscionable.
question: Why does presenting a specific counterexample to the contention that direct mail advertising is not immoral not accurately describe Durth's method of reasoning?
answers: The husband is not penalizing the wife for signing a prenuptial agreement and is instead breaking the original agreement.
He states that the practice is annoying, not that people find it annoying. There is no reason given for why the mail is thrown out.
Whether or not the other party abides by its part of the agreement, the ethicist questions the morality of seeking restitution after agreeing in writing to not.
There was no mention of the other side of the argument. Only the argummnt that it is immoral was presented.
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following most accurately describes Durth's method of reasoning?
main_answers: claiming that direct mail advertising is immoral because one of its results would be deemed immoral in other contexts
asserting that other advertising methods do not have the negative effects of direct mail advertising
presenting a specific counterexample to the contention that direct mail advertising is not immoral
basing a conclusion on the claim that direct mail advertising is annoying to those who receive it
others.target_option: presenting a specific counterexample to the contention that direct mail advertising is not immoral

context: A major network news organization experienced a drop in viewership in the week following the airing of a controversial report on the economy. The network also received a very large number of complaints regarding the report. The network, however, maintains that negative reactions to the report had nothing to do with its loss of viewers.
question: Explain why the fact that major network news organizations publicly attribute drops in viewership to their own reports only when they receive complaints about those reports does not strongly support the network's position.
answers: The network received complaints about the report and did not attribute that to drops in viewership.
If other major network news organizations experienced similar reductions in viewership during the same time period, there could be another factor influencing the reduction.
Whether those registering complaints were regular viewers or not would not change whether or not there was a drop in viewership.
None of the above choices
label: A

context: For the condor to survive in the wild, its breeding population must be greatly increased. But because only a few eggs can be produced by a breeding pair over their lifetime, any significant increase in the number of birds depends upon most of these eggs hatching, which is extremely unlikely in the wild due to environmental dangers. One possible way to eliminate the effects of these factors is to breed the birds in captivity and subsequently return them to the wild.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that it is almost impossible to eliminate all the environmental threats to the eggs of condors based on the information provided?
answers: The argument of the passage is to change the breeding location rather than alter the number of eggs produced.
The passage indicates that low number of eggs hatching in the wild could threaten its long term survival.
The passage actually suggests one viable way to eliminate or minimize existing environmental threats.
The elimination of the species is not an outcome that the passage suggests is unavoidable.

context: Advertisement for a lactase supplement: Lactase, an enzyme produced by the body, aids in the digestion of lactose, a natural sugar found in dairy foods. Many subjects in an experiment who drank a liter of milk on an empty stomach showed signs of lactose intolerance -- difficulty in digesting dairy products because of insufficient lactase. Thus, extrapolating from the number of subjects adversely affected, at least 50 million people in North America alone should take lactase supplements.
question: Why does the fact that lactose intolerance can interfere with proper nutrition not seriously weaken the argument?
answers: The effects of lactose on nutrition does not affect a person's tolerance for lactose.
If jokes do not conform to patterns but rather break them, then they would be more difficult to remember as the brains remembers best with repeated patterns.

label: A

main_answers: Lactose intolerance can interfere with proper nutrition.

Most people who consume dairy products consume less lactose at each meal than the amount found in a liter of milk.
Eating solid food when drinking milk can decrease the amount of lactase produced by the body.
others.target_option: Lactose intolerance can interfere with proper nutrition.

context: Brand X, which currently markets luxury watches via billboards and advertisements in popular magazines, is considering saving money by advertising its newest line of luxury watches only in niche publications read by the wealthy. context: Consumers will be hurt by the new lower ceilings on halibut catches. Given the law of supply and demand these restrictions are likely to result in an increase in the price of the fish.
question: How does assuming that the demand for halibut will not decrease substantially after the new restrictions are imposed justify the claim that the price of halibut will increase?
answers: Lower supply does not generally lead to lower demand, in fact the opposite is generally true as an economic principle, as more people will still desire the halibut though fewer will be available.
The amount of halibut consumed as a proportion of other fish cannot be assumed to be impactful as the author only notes the supply level of this specific fish lowering.
The demand for other fish, whether increasing or decreasing, does not affect the price or availability of halibut.

While there is a connection between the supply of halibut and the demand of halibut, there is no way to tell which direction that connection would go without being more specific thus halibut prices could go down just as easily as up.
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if assumed, would do most to justify the claim that the price of halibut will increase?
main_answers: The demand for halibut will not decrease substantially after the new restrictions are imposed.
The demand for other fish will be affected by the new restrictions.
There is a connection between the supply of halibut and the demand for it.
The amount of halibut consumed represents a very small proportion of all fish consumed.
others.target_option: The demand for halibut will not decrease substantially after the new restrictions are imposed.

context: One of the most vexing problems in historiography is dating an event when the usual sources offer conflicting chronologies of the event. Historians should attempt to minimize the number of competing sources, perhaps by eliminating the less credible ones. Once this is achieved and several sources are left, as often happens, historians may try, though on occasion unsuccessfully, to determine independently of the usual sources which date is more likely to be right.
question: Why is it not valid to infer that attaching a reliable date to any event requires determining which of several conflicting chronologies is most likely to be true based on the information provided?
answers: The virus is diluted so much in human blood that it would be difficult to give it to someone else.
The virus is carried by mosquitoes because humans cannot pass it on to others as the virus is too diluted in the blood stream.
Undermining credibility of sources is not necessarily part of the process of the passage, rather the passage states that it is important to eliminate chronologies that may be less credible.
Attaching reliable dates to events does not necessarily have anything to do with determining which chronologies are true or false.
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following inferences is most strongly supported by the information above?
main_answers: Attaching a reliable date to any event requires determining which of several conflicting chronologies is most likely to be true.
The soundest approach to dating an event for which the usual sources give conflicting chronologies is to undermine the credibility of as many of these sources as possible.
Some of the events for which there are conflicting chronologies and for which attempts have been made by historians to determine the right date cannot be dated reliably by historians.
We have no plausible chronology of most of the events for which attempts have been made by historians to determine the right date.
others.target_option: Attaching a reliable date to any event requires determining which of several conflicting chronologies is most likely to be true.

context: Debater: As a pedagogical practice, lecturing embodies hierarchy, since the lecturer is superior to the student in mastery of the subject. But people learn best from peer interaction. Thus, the hierarchy in lecturing is a great weakness. Respondent: By definition, all teaching and learning are hierarchical, for all teaching and learning must proceed from simple to complex. In teaching mathematics, for example, arithmetic must precede calculus. Thus, the hierarchy in lecturing is a strength.
question: Why is the respondent's reply to the debater's argument not considered to be flawed for assuming that the conceptual structure of mathematics is sufficiently representative of the conceptual structure of at least some other academic disciplines?
answers: Even if some characteristics of lecturing other than hierarchy are weaknesses, they are not the characteristics the Debater is talking about which are the characteristics of hierarchy.

The Respondent does concede the Debater's major assumption that teaching and learning are hierarchical, but he is talking about a different type of hierarchy than the Debater is. The Debater is talking about the hierarchy that exists between teacher and student and the Respondent is talking about the hierarchy that exists in the passage from beginning to complex topics.

Even if it does take this for granted, it is not the hierarchical structure the Debater is talking about. The Debater is talking about the hierarch that exists between student and teacher, not the hierarchy that exists in the structure of a discipline like math.

The Repondent does apply the key concept of hierarchy to a different aspect of education (the passage from simpler to complex topics) than the aspect to which the debater applied the key concept of hierarchy (the one that exists between teacher and student.)
label: C

context: Edwina: True appreciation of Mozart' s music demands that you hear it exactly as he intended it to be heard; that is, exactly as he heard it. After all, Mozart was writing at a time when the performer was expected, as a matter of course, not just to interpret but to modify the written score.

answers: He is not concerned with the idea of authenticity, but is instead showing that Edwina is being too rigid because she doesn't understand the historical context of the composition.

context: The basic ingredients from which cement is made are both cheap and plentiful. Materials as common as limestone and clay will do. answers: How well frogs of different sizes coexist is irrelevant to the author's conclusion.
This cannot be logically inferred from the passage because the passage shows a correlation between the two and if anything when oil prices rise cement prices would rise as well.
The passage argues that smaller frogs are more vulnerable due to lower weight to skin surface ratio, not the permeability of their skin.

The passage states that large amounts of energy are used by kilns and that the price of cement if influenced by the price of oil, so it can be inferred that oil is used for energy in some kilns when making cement.
label: B

main_answers: Whenever oil prices rise, cement prices drop.

Oil is one of the basic ingredients that make up cement.

context: The word "loophole" is a loaded, partisan word, one that implies wrongdoing and scandal. When "loophole" creeps into news stories, they start to read like editorials. So news reporters should not use the term "loophole" in their stories unless they provide evidence of wrongdoing.
question: Explain why the principle that making use of a loophole never constitutes wrongdoing or scandal does not help to justify the reasoning in the argument.
answers: The passage says a loophole can be used when there is evidence of wrongdoing.
The argument addresses the reality of alcohol regulation rather than attempting to carry out a cost benefit analysis.
The harmful effects are discussed but not a conclusion to be inferred from the passage as a whole.
The passage mentions "loophole" as a vague term often used in a negative connotation. This option bolsters why the term should not be used lightly in newspapers unless there is factual evidence.
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following principles, if valid, most helps to justify the reasoning in the argument?
main_answers: Making use of a loophole never constitutes wrongdoing or scandal.
News stories need to give evidence to back up any suggestions of misconduct.
Editorials should meet the same journalistic standards as news stories.
Editorial writers should be free to use loaded, partisan words.
others.target_option: Making use of a loophole never constitutes wrongdoing or scandal.

context: Winston: The Public Transportation Authority (PTA) cannot fulfill its mandate to operate without a budget deficit unless it eliminates service during late-night periods of low ridership. Since the fares collected during these periods are less than the cost of providing the service, these cuts would reduce the deficit and should be made. Transit law prohibits unauthorized fare increases, and fare-increase authorization would take two years. Ping: Such service cuts might cost the PTA more in lost fares than they would save in costs, for the PTA would lose those riders who leave home during the day but must return late at night. Thus the PTA would lose two fares, while realizing cost savings for only one leg of such trips.
question: Why does Ping's response not carefully redefine a term used in Winston's argument in relation to Winston's argument?
answers: Ping's response is based on a situation, not a premise.
Ping raises a point not taken into account by Winston.
Ping's response does not rely on statistical evidence, but rather uses a general example.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The relationship of Ping's response to Winston's argument is that Ping's response
main_answers: carefully redefines a term used in Winston's argument
questions Winston's proposal by raising considerations not addressed by Winston
introduces detailed statistical evidence that is more persuasive than that offered by Winston
supplies a premise that could have been used as part of the support for Winston's argument
others.target_option: carefully redefines a term used in Winston's argument

context: Archaeologist: How did the Parthenon' s stonemasons manage to carve columns that all bulged outward in the center in precisely the same way? One hypothesis is suggested by the discovery of a scale drawing of a column etched into the stone of a Greek temple at Didyma. The drawing is a profile view of a column surrounded by a grid, which makes it possible to determine the correct width at every height of the column. The stonemasons who carved the Parthenon' s columns may have relied on a drawing like the one at Didyma.
question: Why does the fact that the construction of the temple at Didyma was begun over a century after the Parthenon was constructed not add support for the archaeologist's hypothesis?
answers: Reduced vulnerability to adverse weather conditions is clearly a valuable property for any crop to possess.
Reduction in wholesale price due to the laws of supply and demand would not effect the profitability of the crop, as more of it could also be grown on the same amount of land.
If the columns are not comparable in size, it makes it more likely that different construction techniques were used to create them.
The farther apart in time the two temples were constructed, the more likely they were to have relied on different construction techniques.
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, adds the most support for the archaeologist's hypothesis?
main_answers: The construction of the temple at Didyma was begun over a century after the Parthenon was constructed.
The surviving columns at Didyma are almost twice as tall as the columns at the Parthenon.
Scale drawings were commonly used in many types of construction in ancient Greece.
Modern attempts to recreate columns like those at the Parthenon have only been partially successful.
others.target_option: The construction of the temple at Didyma was begun over a century after the Parthenon was constructed.

context: Professor: Unfortunately, pharmaceutical companies and other profit-driven institutions provide nearly all of the funding for the chemistry department' s research. Moreover, unless we can secure more funding for basic science research, it is highly unlikely that any significant advances in basic research will come out of the department. Thus, without increased funding from sources other than profit-driven institutions, the chemistry department is unlikely to gain the prestige that only achievements in basic science research confer.
question: What is the basis for the professor's argument not relying on the assumption that if the chemistry department's prestige increases substantially, then it is highly likely that the department's funding from sources other than profit-driven institutions will subsequently increase?
answers: The passage does not mention this, they may benefit and they have other reasons to not fund that type of research.
The passage is not saying that it should forego the funding just that there needs to be a source to fund other parts of the department.
The passage mentions that the for profit companies are only interested in funding one type of research, this would make you assume that the money will have to come from another source.

The passage is talking about how without funding there is no chance of increasing their prestige, therefore it would be irresponsible to assume that they could increase their prestige without more money.
label: D

main_answers: If the chemistry department's prestige increases substantially, then it is highly likely that the department's funding from sources other than profit-driven institutions will subsequently increase.
The chemistry department's funding for basic science research is not likely to increase if its funding from sources other than profit-driven institutions does not increase.

Members of the chemistry department are unlikely to make significant advances in basic science research if the department does not forego the funding it currently receives from profit-driven institutions.
The profit-driven institutions that currently provide almost all of the chemistry department's funding are not likely to benefit from basic scientific research.

question: What is the reasoning behind the professor's argument relying on the assumption that the chemistry department's funding for basic science research is not likely to increase if its funding from sources other than profit-driven institutions does not increase?
answers: The passage is not saying that it should forego the funding just that there needs to be a source to fund other parts of the department.

The passage is talking about how without funding there is no chance of increasing their prestige, therefore it would be irresponsible to assume that they could increase their prestige without more money.
The passage mentions that the for profit companies are only interested in funding one type of research, this would make you assume that the money will have to come from another source.
The passage does not mention this, they may benefit and they have other reasons to not fund that type of research.

context: Journalist: Many people working on difficult problems in mathematics report going to sleep without a solution, but upon awaking discover they have a solution in mind. This phenomenon occurs among all age groups past infancy.

answers: The author assumes that the brain continues to develop at higher rates as the person grows and develops.

context: A new government policy has been developed to avoid many serious cases of influenza. This goal will be accomplished by the annual vaccination of high-risk individuals: everyone 65 and older as well as anyone with a chronic disease that might cause them to experience complications from the influenza virus. Each year' s vaccination will protect only against the strain of the influenza virus deemed most likely to be prevalent that year, so every year it will be necessary for all high-risk individuals to receive a vaccine for a different strain of the virus.
question: What is the basis for the conclusion not being properly drawn even if it is assumed that the number of individuals in the high-risk group for influenza will not significantly change from year to year?
answers: It is possible that a vaccine protects against multiple strains of influenza, but that doesn't mean that a new strain can not develop that was not covered by a vaccine regardless of the number of strains that vaccine covered.
The author argues that it is necessary to get vaccinations every year because of the different strains, and the likelihood of there being an epidemic at all isn't relevant.

If the strain of influenza prevalent one year was the same from a prior year, then at least some high-risk people would already be vaccinated for that strain and would therefore not need to be vaccinated again.
How many people fall into the high-risk group would not be relevant to the differing strains and the necessity to vaccinate against them for all high-risk people.
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption that would allow the conclusion above to be properly drawn?
main_answers: The number of individuals in the high-risk group for influenza will not significantly change from year to year.
The likelihood that a serious influenza epidemic will occur varies from year to year.
Each year the strain of influenza virus deemed most likely to be prevalent will be one that had not previously been deemed most likely to be prevalent.
No vaccine for the influenza virus protects against more than one strain of that virus.
others.target_option: The number of individuals in the high-risk group for influenza will not significantly change from year to year.

context: Adult frogs are vulnerable to dehydration because of their highly permeable skins. None of the above choices
label: B

context: During construction of the Quebec Bridge in 1907, the bridge' s designer, Theodore Cooper, received word that the suspended span being built out from the bridge' s cantilever was deflecting downward by a fraction of an inch. Before he could telegraph to freeze the project, the whole cantilever arm broke off and plunged, along with seven dozen workers, into the St. Lawrence River. It was the worst bridge construction disaster in history. As a direct result of the inquiry that followed, the engineering "rules of thumb" by which thousands of bridges had been built went down with the Quebec Bridge. Twentieth-century bridge engineers would thereafter depend on far more rigorous applications of mathematical analysis.
question: Explain why it is not valid to infer that Cooper's absence from the Quebec Bridge construction site resulted in the breaking off of the cantilever from the passage?
answers: The passage implies that the bridge was built using those rules of thumb which is why those rules of thumb were discarded, and that bridge collapsed, so clearly those rules of thumb were insufficient.

Cooper being at the construction site would entail many different details to the story and it's entirely plausible that he would not have been aware of the issue or still would not have been able to freeze the project in time.

The passage states that the mathematical rules of thumb for bridges built beforehand were abandoned, but it is possible that bridges prior to that were built with more rigorous standards than those rules of thumb.
The passage implies that the rules of thumb did include analytical methods, and that they were merely inferior analytical methods than what came after.
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following statements can be properly inferred from the passage?
main_answers: Cooper's absence from the Quebec Bridge construction site resulted in the breaking off of the cantilever.
Bridges built before about 1907 were built without thorough mathematical analysis and, ttherefore, were unsafe for the public to use.
Nineteenth-century bridge engineers relied on their rules of thumb because analytical methods were inadequate to solve their design problems.
Prior to 1907 the mathematical analysis incorporated in engineering rules of thumb was insufficient to completely assure the safety of bridges under construction.
others.target_option: Cooper's absence from the Quebec Bridge construction site resulted in the breaking off of the cantilever.

context: Global ecological problems reduce to the problem of balancing supply and demand. Supply is strictly confined by the earth' s limitations. Demand, however, is essentially unlimited, as there are no limits on the potential demands made by humans. The natural tendency for there to be an imbalance between demand and sustainable supply is the source of these global problems. Ttherefore, any solutions require reducing current human demand.

answers: Human demand exceeding the earth's sustainable supply is what is explicitly being discussed and addressed as the problem needing to be corrected.

Human consumption does decrease the environmental supply as the environmental supply is limited.
None of the above choices

main_answers: Human consumption does not decrease the environmental supply.

Supply and demand tend to balance themselves in the long run.
others.target_option: Human consumption does not decrease the environmental supply.

context: Chronic back pain is usually caused by a herniated or degenerated spinal disk. In most cases the disk will have been damaged years before chronic pain develops, and in fact an estimated one in five people over the age of 30 has a herniated or degenerated disk that shows no chronic symptoms. If chronic pain later develops in such a case, it is generally brought about by a deterioration of the abdominal and spinal muscles caused by insufficient exercise.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that the statements above strongly support the claim that four out of five people over the age of 30 can be sure they will never develop chronic back pain?
answers: An estimated one in five people means that there's a possibility of there being more than one in five people over who will develop chronic back pain.

The passage states that chronic back pain is usually caused by herniated or degenerated spinal disk, which means that there are also other causes and makes no claims about whether those can be accurately predicted.

If most cases of chronic back pain developed later in life are caused by insufficient exercise leading to a deterioration of those muscles, then it follows that exercise would cause those muscles to be less deteriorated, which would delay or prevent chronic back pain.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: The statements above, if true, most strongly support which one of the following?
main_answers: Four out of five people over the age of 30 can be sure they will never develop chronic back pain.
Doctors can accurately predict which people who do not have chronic back pain will develop it in the future.
People who exercise their abdominal and spinal muscles regularly are sure to be free from chronic back pain.
There is a strategy that can be effective in delaying or preventing the onset of pain from a currently asymptomatic herniated or degenerated spinal disk.
others.target_option: Four out of five people over the age of 30 can be sure they will never develop chronic back pain.

context: Statistical records of crime rates probably often reflect as much about the motives and methods of those who compile or cite them as they do about the actual incidence of crime. The police may underreport crime in order to convey the impression of their own success or overreport crime to make the case for a budget increase. Politicians may magnify crime rates to get elected or minimize them to remain in office. Newspapers, of course, often sensationalize crime statistics to increase readership.
question: What is the reason for the argument not proceeding by deriving implications of a generalization that it assumes to be true?
answers: This passage is giving examples of a claim, not generalizing anything.
Nothing in this passage contradicts its conclusion.
The passage starts out saying that crime rates really don't matter and proceeds to give reasons why they are misleading.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: The argument proceeds by doing which one of the following?
main_answers: deriving implications of a generalization that it assumes to be true
citing examples in support of its conclusion
enumerating problems for which it proposes a general solution
showing how evidence that apparently contradicts its conclusion actually supports that conclusion
others.target_option: deriving implications of a generalization that it assumes to be true

context: Capuchin monkeys in Venezuela often rub a certain type of millipede into their fur. Secretions of these millipedes have been shown to contain two chemicals that are potent mosquito repellents, and mosquitoes carry parasites that debilitate the capuchins. The rubbing behavior is rare except during the rainy season, when mosquito populations are at their peak. Ttherefore, the monkeys probably rub the millipedes into their fur because doing so helps protect them against mosquitoes.
question: What evidence is needed to evaluate the argument to determine whether the two chemicals provide any protection for the millipedes against their own predators?
answers: The argument concerns the motivations for an action undertaken by the monkeys, not by the millipedes. The millipedes' protection or otherwise from mosquitos is therefore irrelevant, as it is the monkeys' protection which could affect their motivation.

By saying that formal instruction is often a part of receiving a good musical education, it does seem to imply that there are times when formal instruction is not part of receiving a good musical education

It is very likely that the formal education and musical education will be provided by instructors other than the parents themselves and so there is no contesting that the parents might not be the only source of a child's musical education
The actions of unspecified animals in rubbing insects whose protective is unknown cannot tell us anything about the specific actions of capuchins with a know protective element.
label: A

main_answers: Whether the two chemicals provide any protection for the millipedes against their own predators
Whether animals other than capuchins rub insects of any kind into their fur
Whether the type of millipede used by the capuchin monkeys in Venezuela is found in other parts of the world
Whether the only time the millipedes are readily available to the capuchins is during the rainy season
others.target_option: Whether the two chemicals provide any protection for the millipedes against their own predators

context: The Dvorak keyboard requires less finger movement than the ubiquitous QWERTY keyboard. As a result, Dvorak keyboard users are not only able to type more words per minute, but are also less vulnerable to both repetitive stress disorder and carpal tunnel syndrome. Nonetheless, businesses, as well as consumers, have not adopted the Dvorak keyboard. Clearly, if the Dvorak keyboard is to become more widely used, its benefits must be more widely touted.
question: Explain why the fact that those suffering from repetitive stress injuries often attribute the injuries to multiple factors does not cast doubt on the author's conclusion?
answers: This would more than anything else support the author's view as people are not aware that the Dvorak keyboard exists and therefore would not know of the benefits it contains.

If a strike can be obviated by a salary increase and consequences which would be expected to arise from such a salary increase are observed, it is reasonable to assume that a salary increase has been made and thus that the strike will not occur.

Injuries being attributed to multiple factors really plays no role in anything concerning the author's conclusion as it is stated that stress disorders and carpal tunnel syndrome are factors attributed to the QWERTY keyboard.
The argument explicitly states that only a salary increase will prevent a strike; assumptions that alternatives would not be acceptable do not need to be made.
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, casts the most doubt on the author's conclusion?
main_answers: Those suffering from repetitive stress injuries often attribute the injuries to multiple factors
Businesses have found that many employees who believe the QWERTY keyboard is responsible for stress-induced injuries are unaware of the Dvorak keyboard.
Many who have attempted using a Dvorak keyboard claim that learning the configuration of keys takes weeks
Businesses that have educated employees on the benefits of the Dvorak keyboard, have found that employees continue to use the QWERTY keyboard
others.target_option: Those suffering from repetitive stress injuries often attribute the injuries to multiple factors

context: Company policy: An employee of our company must be impartial, particularly when dealing with family members. This obligation extends to all aspects of the job, including hiring and firing practices and the quality of service the employee provides customers.
question: Why does the behavior of never firing a family member, even though three of one's siblings work under one's supervision and authority not clearly violate the company policy cited above?
answers: It is not clear that there is a legitimate reason to fire the family member so it is not clear that not firing them shows that a person is not being impartial.
The company policy states that an employee must be impartial but if the siblings are qualified but one still refuses to hire them it shows that one has bias and is not impartial.
In this case the mother is receiving the same treatment as the other people so this does not violate the policy of being impartial.
Although the offences have not occurred for over two years, refusing to advance the employee may not be due to a person not being impartial.
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following employee behaviors most clearly violates the company policy cited above?
main_answers: never firing a family member, even though three of one's siblings work under one's supervision and authority
refusing to hire any of one's five siblings, even though they are each more qualified than any other applicant
repeatedly refusing to advance an employee, claiming that he has sometimes skipped work and that his work has been sloppy, even though no such instances have occurred for over two years
receiving over a hundred complaints about the service one's office provides and sending a complimentary product to all those who complain, including one's mother
others.target_option: never firing a family member, even though three of one's siblings work under one's supervision and authority

context: As regards memory, the brain responds best to repeated patterns, such as the melodic and rhythmic patterns of music. This is why we can remember long strings of information or text, which would normally be impossible to memorize, when they are put to music. Given that music aids memory, it might seem that funny jokes would be easy to remember, since, like music, they normally elicit an emotional response in us. However, jokes are usually very difficult to remember, since . __.
question: Why does the fact that, for most people, certain memories elicit a strong emotional response not logically complete the passage?
answers: A joke would be considered a patterned piece of information similar to music.
If certain memories cause a strong emotional response, then it follows that jokes would be easier to remember as they also elicit an emotional response.
If Neanderthals kept gazelle teeth for use in rituals, they may have brought some of the teeth from other settlements when moving.
This supports the idea that the Neanderthals hunted the gazelles in one place year-round.
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following most logically completes the passage?
main_answers: for most people, certain memories elicit a strong emotional response
people can hold in short-term memory only a few chunks of unpattemed information at a time
jokes work not by conforming to repeated patterns but by breaking them
jokes, unlike music, always have content that is verbal or at least clearly symbolic
others.target_option: for most people, certain memories elicit a strong emotional response
