context: Aerobics instructor: Compared to many forms of exercise, kickboxing aerobics is highly risky. Overextending when kicking often leads to hip, knee, or lower-back injuries. Such overextension is very likely to occur when beginners try to match the high kicks of more skilled practitioners.
question: What evidence does the aerobics instructor provide to strongly support the claim that beginners at kickboxing aerobics should avoid trying to match the high kicks of more skilled practitioners in order to reduce the risk of injuries?
answers: Even if this option were true it's not the conclusion that the argument is coming to.
Beginners could suffer injuries because of other reasons besides just trying to match the high kicks.

The argument says that the high risk is due to the fact that beginners try to match the high kicks of more skilled practitioners, so the argument is suggesting that beginners should avoid trying that.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the aerobics instructor's statements?
main_answers: Kickboxing aerobics is more risky than forms of aerobic exercise that do not involve high kicks.
To reduce the risk of injuries, beginners at kickboxing aerobics should avoid trying to match the high kicks of more skilled practitioners.
Beginners at kickboxing aerobics will not experience injuries if they avoid trying to match the high kicks of more skilled practitioners.
Skilled practitioners of kickboxing aerobics are unlikely to experience injuries from overextending while kicking.
others.target_option: To reduce the risk of injuries, beginners at kickboxing aerobics should avoid trying to match the high kicks of more skilled practitioners.

context: Some people prefer to avoid facing unpleasant truths and resent those whose unwanted honesty forces them into such a confrontation. Others dislike having any information, however painful, knowingly withheld from them. It is obvious then that if those in the former group are guided by the directive to treat others as they themselves want to be treated, __.
question: Why does the fact that people will sometimes withhold comment in situations in which they would otherwise be willing to speak not reasonably complete the argument?
answers: Withholding comments where you would otherwise normally speak is treating yourselves how you want to be treated rather than treating others.
Those in the latter group are not the ones supposed to be guided by treating others how they themselves want to be treated.
It is unknown by what principles the latter group are guided by, if they are even guided by any principle of behavior in the first place.

If the former and latter group's preferences regarding information are contradictory, and the former group treats others as they want to be treated, it is inevitable that they will sometimes treat the latter group how they treat themselves.
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following most reasonably completes the argument above?
main_answers: they will sometimes withhold comment in situations in which they would otherwise be willing to speak
those in the latter group will respond by concealing unpleasant truths
they will sometimes treat those in the latter group in a manner the members of this latter group do not like
those in the latter group must be guided by an entirely different principle of behavior
others.target_option: they will sometimes withhold comment in situations in which they would otherwise be willing to speak

context: Legal commentator: The goal of a recently enacted law that bans smoking in workplaces is to protect employees from secondhand smoke. But the law is written in such a way that it cannot be interpreted as ever prohibiting people from smoking in their own homes.
question: Why is it not justified to reject the claim that most people believe that smokers have a fundamental right to smoke in their own homes based on the statements above?
answers: This supports the passage because it states that most people believe smokers have a right to smoke in their own homes and the law is written so that it cannot prohibit people from doing exactly that.

This is not supported because the passage states that the law cannot be interpreted as prohibiting people from smoking in their own homes.  This would not protect domestic workers from secondhand smoke in their workplaces because the people who live in the homes they are working at would be allowed to smoke.
While this may be true, is does not reject the claim that the law will be successful in protecting people's health in their placed of work.
This would support the law rather than reject it as it tells us that many believe the law will succeed in protecting the health of many.
label: A

main_answers: Most people believe that smokers have a fundamental right to smoke in their own homes.
The law offers no protection from secondhand smoke for people outside of their workplaces.
The law will protect domestic workers such as housecleaners from secondhand smoke in their workplaces.
Supporters of the law believe that it will have a significant impact on the health of many workers.
others.target_option: Most people believe that smokers have a fundamental right to smoke in their own homes.

context: In a study of the effect of radiation from nuclear weapons plants on people living in areas near them, researchers compared death rates in the areas near the plants with death rates in areas that had no such plants. Finding no difference in these rates, the researchers concluded that radiation from the nuclear weapons plants poses no health hazards to people living near them.
question: How does the fact that exposure to nuclear radiation can cause many serious diseases that do not necessarily result in death weaken the researchers' argument?
answers: Their researchers conclusion only concerns effects on residents living near nuclear power plants, and so would not be undermined by any effects on people not residing in such an area.

As the researchers studied only death rates, the presence of non-fatal health effects do to any radiation from the plants would remain undetected and thus could seriously undermine the conclusion that such plants cause no health effects whatsoever.
A small sample size due to the rarity of such plants might somewhat reduce the level confidence in the researchers results, but it does not actually contradict them.
None of the above choices
label: B

main_answers: Only a small number of areas have nuclear weapons plants.
Nuclear power plants were not included in the study.
Exposure to nuclear radiation can cause many serious diseases that do not necessarily result in death.
The researchers did not study the possible health hazards of radiation on people who were employed at the nuclear weapons plants if those employees did not live in the study areas.
others.target_option: Exposure to nuclear radiation can cause many serious diseases that do not necessarily result in death.

context: Frequently, people who diet to lose weight become trapped in a vicious cycle. When those people diet, they not only lose weight, but their bodies become used to fewer calories and become accustomed to functioning at that lower rate of caloric intake. As a result, when they stop dieting and go back to eating amounts of food that would have just maintained their weight in the days before the diet, they take in far more calories than they need. Those excess calories produce excess weight.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that people who diet to lose weight are bound to end up weighing more than when they started dieting based on the passage?
answers: Not dieting as a solution cannot be assumed from the passage.  We can assume that dieting is not the issue based upon the information, rather the issue lies with returning to intaking their pre-diet amounts of food.
We are not told that the people end up weighing more than when they started dieting in the passage, only that they return to their pre-diet amounts of food intake.

We are told in the passage that those who become trapped in the cycle gain weight back by returning to eating their pre-diet amounts of food.  Therefore we can conclude that not going back to their pre-diet amount of food will help people who are dieting to remain on track.
We are not given information in the passage as to whether or not this is possible.  Perhaps some people can go back to their pre-diet intake with enough exercise, but we cannot know from the passage.
label: B

others.main_question: The passage above best supports which one of the following conclusions about people who diet to lose weight?
main_answers: They are bound to end up weighing more than when they started dieting.
They must not go back to eating pre-diet amounts of food if they are to maintain their weight at the reduced level resulting from dieting.
They never can go back to their pre-diet caloric intake without regaining all of the weight lost by dieting.
They should not diet if they desire to maintain their reduced weight.
others.target_option: They are bound to end up weighing more than when they started dieting.

context: Double-blind techniques should be used whenever possible in scientific experiments. They help prevent the misinterpretations that often arise due to expectations and opinions that scientists already hold, and clearly scientists should be extremely diligent in trying to avoid such misinterpretations.
question: What is the reasoning behind the conclusion that it is advisable for scientists to use double-blind techniques in as high a proportion of their experiments as they can?
answers: The focus of the passage is on how to prevent these misinterpretations, not on whether the scientists are aware of their risk.
The author believes that extra diligence should be shown by the scientist to avoid letting their biases taint the experiment by using double-blind techniques.
The focus of the article is not on how often the double-blind techniques are effective but on how often they should be used.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following most accurately expresses the main conclusion of the argument?
main_answers: It is advisable for scientists to use double-blind techniques in as high a proportion of their experiments as they can.
Scientists sometimes neglect to adequately consider the risk of misinterpreting evidence on the basis of prior expectations and opinions.
Scientists' objectivity may be impeded by interpreting experimental evidence on the basis of expectations and opinions that they already hold.
Double-blind experimental techniques are often an effective way of ensuring scientific objectivity.
others.target_option: It is advisable for scientists to use double-blind techniques in as high a proportion of their experiments as they can.

context: S: Our nation is becoming too averse to risk. We boycott any food reported to contain a toxic chemical, even though the risk, as a mathematical ratio, might be minimal. T: A risk-taker in one context can be risk-averse in another: the same person can drive recklessly, but refuse to eat food not grown organically.

context: Taste buds were the primary tool early humans used for testing foods. Sour taste warns of possible spoilage of food while bitterness is a warning of many poisons. Early humans also recognized sweet foods and salty foods as meeting nutritional needs. So the fact that people can now clearly distinguish these four tastes-sour, bitter, sweet, and salty-is completely explained by people' s use of taste to test for the healthfulness of foods.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument not considered to be flawed for taking a necessary condition for the truth of its conclusion to be sufficient to justify that conclusion?
answers: The author looks at one explanation and fails to consider that there are other explanations that also may be true.
The author does not consider that there are other ways to determine the healthiness of a food and that taste can just be one explanation.
The paleontologist is arguing that life was likely to have begun on land. So this information may definitely help the main argument.
None of the above choices
label: A

main_answers: takes a necessary condition for the truth of its conclusion to be sufficient to justify that conclusion
takes what might be only a partial explanation of a phenomenon to be the complete explanation
fails to consider that many people associate foods more with their smells than with their tastes
fails to consider that some nutritious foods are bitter when raw but not after being cooked
others.target_option: takes a necessary condition for the truth of its conclusion to be sufficient to justify that conclusion

context: Bookstore owner: Consumers should buy books only from an independent bookstore, not from a bookstore that belongs to a bookstore chain. An independent bookstore tends to carry a much wider variety of books than does a chain bookstore, so because chains often threaten the existence of independent bookstores, they tend to reduce the variety of books available to consumers.
question: Explain why the principle that consumers should not make purchases from any bookstore that deliberately forces competing bookstores out of business does not help to justify the bookstore owner's argumentation.
answers: The passage does not make any mention of the interests of book selling businesses.

The owners' argument if followed would put chain book stores out of business, so if this principle was true, you could not shop from a bookstore with an owner that believes the argument in the passage.
The argument in the passage seems to mainly focus on independent stores going out of business rather than the actual book diversity.
The passage and this principle are in agreement that bookstores with a high variety of books are where customers should shop.
label: B

main_answers: Consumers should not make purchases from any bookstore that deliberately forces competing bookstores out of business.
If consumers have no access to any independent bookstore, they should buy books from the chain bookstore with the greatest diversity of books.
Consumers should buy books from only those bookstores whose existence does not tend to reduce the variety of books available to consumers.
The best interest of the bookselling business is not served when consumers purchase books from businesses whose existence tends to reduce the variety of books available to consumers.
others.target_option: Consumers should not make purchases from any bookstore that deliberately forces competing bookstores out of business.

context: John: For 40 years, fluoride has been added to public drinking water. According to a study, fluoridated public drinking water when given to laboratory rats causes bone cancer. Ninety percent of all the male rats in the test sample were affected, but the female rats were unaffected. Even though I am healthy now, I should nevertheless stop drinking fluoridated water; only then will I be sure not to develop bone cancer.
question: Explain why the fact that John does not consider whether fluoridated water causes other diseases does not constitute the strongest criticism of John's reasoning.
answers: Even if fluoride was not added to the water during brief periods in the past, the water that John drinks today would still be fluoridated.
If John stops drinking fluoridated water, it is still possible that he develops bone cancer from other causes.
The positive effects of fluoridated water do not change the fact that it is possible for it to cause bone cancer.
Whether fluoridated water causes other diseases or not is irrelevant to whether John will develop bone cancer or not.
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following is the strongest criticism of John's reasoning?
main_answers: John does not consider whether fluoridated water causes other diseases.
John does not consider whether there were any brief periods during the 40 years in which fluoride was not added to the water.
John does not consider the possibility of other causes of bone cancer.
John does not focus on the positive effects that fluoridated water has on people
others.target_option: John does not consider whether fluoridated water causes other diseases.

context: Lawyer: If you take something that you have good reason to think is someone else' s property, that is stealing, and stealing is wrong. However, Meyers had no good reason to think that the compost in the public garden was anyone else' s property, so it was not wrong for Meyers to take it.
question: Why is the lawyer's argument considered flawed for taking a condition that by itself is enough to make an action wrong to also be necessary in order for the action to be wrong?
answers: The lawyer claims there wasn't even good reason for Meyers to believe the compost belonged to someone, let alone conclusive proof.
The lawyer is arguing that if he had known the compost had belonged to someone, he would not have taken it.
The lawyer claims you need to know something belongs to someone for it to be stealing to take it.
None of the above choices
label: C

takes for granted that Meyers would not have taken the compost if he had good reason to believe that it was someone else's property

context: Books updating the classification systems used by many libraries are not free -- in fact they are very expensive. The only way to sell copies of them is to make the potential buyers believe they need to adopt the most recent system. Thus, these frequent changes in the classification systems are just a ploy by the publishers to make libraries buy their products.
question: Why is the reasoning not considered to be flawed for concluding that there is no need ever to change classification systems?
answers: The author does not point out other possible benefits and motives for the updating.  The only focus is that it is to soley make money.
A library has limited resources to update their inventory.
Many individuals and schools use books and are thus potential buyers as well.
The assumption would be that as technology progresses that classification systems will need to be updated to keep attracting buyers.
label: D

others.main_question: The reasoning above is most vulnerable to criticism because it
main_answers: concludes that there is no need ever to change classification systems
concludes that a possible ulterior motive must be the only motive
fails to consider that there may be potential buyers of these books other than libraries
fails to consider that the libraries cannot afford to buy every book they want
others.target_option: concludes that there is no need ever to change classification systems

context: Sonya: Anyone who lives without constant awareness of the fragility and precariousness of human life has a mind clouded by illusion. Yet those people who are perpetually cognizant of the fragility and precariousness of human life surely taint their emotional outlook on existence.

Everyone whose emotional outlook on existence is untainted has a mind clouded by illusion.
Either no one has a tainted emotional outlook on existence, or no one has a mind clouded by illusion.
others.target_option: It is impossible for anyone to live without some degree of self-deception.

context: Sonya: Anyone who lives without constant awareness of the fragility and precariousness of human life has a mind clouded by illusion. Yet those people who are perpetually cognizant of the fragility and precariousness of human life surely taint their emotional outlook on existence.
question: What evidence does Sonya's statements provide to support the claim that everyone whose emotional outlook on existence is untainted has a mind clouded by illusion?
answers: Whether awareness or lack of it is not referenced as being better or worse but rather the cause of a particular outlook.
Self deception is not referenced but rather a lack of understanding or acknowledgement as being what affects outlook.
Both possibilities are described which does not eliminate one or the other as a possibility but rather differentiates between the two viewpoints.
AN untainted outlook is said to be achieved through a naiveness of reality.
label: D

context: There have been no new cases of naturally occurring polio in North America in recent years. Yet there are approximately 12 new cases of polio each year in North America, all caused by the commonly administered live oral polio vaccine (OPV). Substituting inactivated polio vaccine (IPV) for most childhood polio immunizations would cut the number of cases of vaccination-caused polio about in half. Clearly it is time to switch from OPV to IPV as the most commonly used polio vaccine for North American children.
question: Why does the fact that most countries with comprehensive child immunization programs use OPV not weaken the argument?
answers: If IPV cuts down the new cases regardless of preexisting conditions, this characteristic of the OPV does not matter.
If naturally occurring polio appears, this means IPV have their own drawbacks in effectiveness that renders them less competitive against OPV.
It is not necessarily wise to follow other countries' immunization programs even if many of them do the same.
Contracting polio from OPV is still a weakness of the vaccine even if it is rare.
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most weakens the argument?
main_answers: Although IPV is preferred in some European nations, most countries with comprehensive child immunization programs use OPV.
The vast majority of cases of polio caused by OPV have occurred in children with preexisting but unsuspected immunodeficiency disorders.
If IPV replaces OPV as the most commonly used polio vaccine, at least a few new cases of naturally occurring polio in North America will result each year.
A child's risk of contracting polio from OPV has been estimated at 1 in 8. 7 million, which is significantly less than the risk of being struck by lightning.
others.target_option: Although IPV is preferred in some European nations, most countries with comprehensive child immunization programs use OPV.

context: A certain tropical island received food donations in the form of powdered milk for distribution to its poorest residents, who were thought to be malnourished. Subsequently, the rate of liver cancers among those islanders increased sharply. The donated milk was probably to blame: recent laboratory research on rats has shown that rats briefly exposed to the substances aflatoxin tend to develop liver cancer when fed casein, a milk protein. This result is relevant because __.
question: What is the basis for not concluding that powdered milk is the most appropriate form in which to send milk to a tropical destination as logically completed by the passage?
answers: Whether or not there are proteins other than casein in the milk would not be relevant to the results of the experiment which depend on casein, which is contained in milk.

If the milk is dangerous to humans because of their combined consumption with aflatoxin as it is with rats, then the island residents consuming aflatoxin as well as the donated milk would explain the health issues.
The experiment about milk interacting with aflatoxin does not relate to what form of milk is best for the people in this region.
The ability of the people to digest milk is not a logical conclusion to an experiment about how the milk reacts with a certain other substance.
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following most logically completes the passage?
main_answers: powdered milk is the most appropriate form in which to send milk to a tropical destination
the people who were given the donated milk had been screened for their ability to digest milk
casein is not the only protein contained in milk
in the tropics, peanuts, a staple of these island residents, support a mold growth that produces aflatoxin
others.target_option: powdered milk is the most appropriate form in which to send milk to a tropical destination

context: Cognitive psychologist: The argument against IQ as a hereditary trait that is fixed throughout one's lifetime ignores the evidence of eye orientation. That is, there is a high correlation between the speed in which a person's eyes orient towards a stimulus and that person's IQ. Specifically, an experiment measured the number of milliseconds subjects required to orient their eyes to the where on a large screen a word was flashed. The study found that the more rapid the response the higher that person's IQ.
question: What is the reason for why the cognitive psychologist does not make the assumption that the speed at which one can orient one's eye to a stimulus has also been highly correlated with overall health?
answers: A person being literate does not necessarily indicate how smart they are.
If the skill could be modified with experience than someone could potentially get better which would argue against the assertion that intelligence is fixed.
The speed of eye orientation is correlated to intelligence, not overall health,.
None of the above choices
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following is an assumption the cognitive psychologist makes?
main_answers: The speed at which one can orient one's eye to a stimulus has also been highly correlated with overall health.
The speed in which a person orients his or her eyes towards a stimulus is a skill that cannot be modified by experience.
The screen used in the experiment was so large that subjects had to shift their bodies in order to read the words presented on the screen.
The ability of scientists to measure a person's IQ depends on whether that person is literate.
others.target_option: The speed at which one can orient one's eye to a stimulus has also been highly correlated with overall health.

context: Oscar: Emerging information technologies will soon make speed of information processing the single most important factor in the creation of individual, corporate, and national wealth. Consequently, the division of the world into northern countries -- in general rich -- and southern countries -- in general poor -- will soon be obsolete. Instead, there simply will be fast countries and slow countries, and thus a country' s economic well-being will not be a function of its geographical position but just a matter of its relative success in incorporating those new technologies. Sylvia: But the poor countries of the south lack the economic resources to acquire those technologies and will ttherefore remain poor. The technologies will thus only widen the existing economic gap between north and south.
question: What evidence is there to suggest that Sylvia's reasoning does not rely on the assumption that there are technologies other than information technologies whose development could help narrow the existing economic gap between north and south?
answers: The passage only suggests that the North's prosperity will allow them to acquire new technologies that the South can't afford, it makes no arguments about where this prosperity came from initially.
Whether the speed of information processing continues to increase or not overall is not necessarily relevant to the relative difference in technology between the North and South.
If, for some reason, the rich countries were ineffective in using these new technologies, any economic disparity would not be attributable to them.
Her reasoning is based on a continued widening of the economic gap rather than any hypothetical technology that could narrow it.
label: D

others.main_question: Sylvia's reasoning depends on the assumption that
main_answers: the speed at which information processing takes place will continue to increase indefinitely
there are technologies other than information technologies whose development could help narrow the existing economic gap between north and south
at least some of the rich countries of the north will be effective in incorporating new information technologies into their economies
the prosperity of the rich countries of the north depends, at least in part, on the natural resources of the poor countries of the south
others.target_option: there are technologies other than information technologies whose development could help narrow the existing economic gap between north and south

context: Compared to us, people who lived a century ago had very few diversions to amuse them. Ttherefore, they likely read much more than we do today.
question: Explain why the fact that many of the books published a century ago were of low literary quality does not weaken the argument.
answers: A book need not have literary quality in order to provide amusement.
The numbers of books sold cannot demonstrate the popularity of books in two different time periods unless information about the size of the population is also given.
Evidence that people had comparatively less leisure time in which to read would undermine the argument that they bought comparatively more books to read.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following statements, if true, most weakens the argument?
main_answers: Many of the books published a century ago were of low literary quality.
The number of books sold today is larger than it was a century ago.
One of the popular diversions of a century ago was horse racing.
On average, people who lived a century ago had considerably less leisure time than we do today.
others.target_option: Many of the books published a century ago were of low literary quality.

context: Winston: The rules for awarding Nobel Prizes stipulate that no more than three people can share the same prize. Nobel Prizes in scientific disciplines are generally given in recognition of particular scientific results, however, and many important results are the work of four or more scientists. Sanjay: Those rules also stipulate that prize winners must be living, but some highly influential scientists died before their work was fully appreciated.
question: What evidence from the dialogue supports the claim that Winston and Sanjay agree that Nobel Prizes are inaccurate indicators of scientists' contributions to their disciplines?
answers: The results are not in question but who gets recognized for the results.

context: Most water companies in the United States add fluoride to tap water to help prevent cavities. Some dentists argue, however, that this practice actually causes more harm than good because people overestimate the protection afforded by the fluoride and do not take the proper steps to care for their teeth, such as brushing and flossing after every meal. If water companies did not add fluoride, the dentists claim, people would be forced to be more active in their dental hygiene and tooth decay would decline as a result.
question: Explain why the fact that most Americans already brush their teeth daily does not weaken the dentists' claims.
answers: Whether fluoride is in dental care products has no bearing on the argument in the passage.
The number of people that visit the dentist is not mentioned in the passage.
The passage says people should brush after every meal, not just once a day.
If most Americans are not aware that tap water has fluoride in it, having it removed wouldn't result in them taking better care of their teeth.
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most weakens the dentists' claims?
main_answers: Most Americans already brush their teeth daily.
Annual visits to the dentist are the most effective means of controlling tooth decay.
Most Americans are not aware that fluoride is added to tap water.
Fluoride is widely used in commercially available dental care products.
others.target_option: Most Americans already brush their teeth daily.

context: Manager: One reason productivity in our office is not as high as it could be is that office workers spend too much time taking unauthorized breaks. Since the number of office workers assigned to each manager will soon be reduced, managers will be able to supervise workers more closely in the future to make sure that they are not taking unauthorized breaks. Ttherefore, productivity in our office will soon increase.
question: What is the reasoning that justifies the conclusion that the manager's argument does not depend on the assumption that supervising employees more closely to reduce unauthorized breaks is the most efficient way of increasing overall office productivity?
answers: Reducing the number of employees and giving those who remain more work does not necessarily decrease the amount of unauthorized breaks those employees still take.
Even if reducing unauthorized breaks is not the most efficient way of increasing productivity, it is still possible for it to be one way to increase productivity.
No financial incentives are being given to workers whose divisions increase productivity.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the manager's argument depends?
main_answers: Supervising employees more closely to reduce unauthorized breaks is the most efficient way of increasing overall office productivity.
The gain in productivity that will result from reducing unauthorized breaks will exceed any loss in productivity caused by closer supervision.
Giving financial incentives to workers whose divisions increase their productivity would not have any significant effect on overall office productivity.
The best way to improve productivity is to reduce the number of employees and give more work to employees who remain on the job.
others.target_option: Supervising employees more closely to reduce unauthorized breaks is the most efficient way of increasing overall office productivity.

context: Art historian: This painting, purportedly by Mary Cassatt, is a forgery. Although the canvas and other materials are consistent with most of Cassatt' s work, and the subject matter is similar to that of Cassatt' s finest paintings, the brush style of this painting is not found in any work known to be Cassatt' s. Hence this painting is definitely not a genuine Cassatt.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that the art historian's argument depends on the assumption that no painter other than Cassatt would be able to match Cassatt's brush style perfectly?
answers: Whether or not another painter can match Cassatt's brush style perfectly is irrelevant since the painting in question has a unique brush style compared to Cassatt's other works.
Cassatt's brush style being the most characteristic feature of her work is irrelevant to whether the uniqueness of the brush style in the painting in question indicates that it is a forgery.
The argument does not rely on the painting's subject matter at all, relying solely on the brush style.

If another one of Cassatt's proven works has a unique brush style, the argument would incorrectly classify that work as a forgery, the argument can only be valid if none of her known works uses a unique brush style.

context: Some scientists believe that the relationship between mice and humans has, over time, diminished the ability of mice to survive in nature, so that now they must depend upon human civilization for their continued existence. This opinion, however, ignores significant facts. Despite numerous predators and humanity' s enmity, mice have distributed themselves more widely across the planet than any other mammal except humans. Mice reproduce rapidly and, more important to their survival, they have the ability to adapt to an extraordinary range of habitats. Should the environment ever become too extreme to support human life, naturalists predict that mice would be able to adapt and survive.
question: Why does the fact that fossil remains prove that mice inhabited North America prior to the arrival of humans not support the naturalists' prediction?
answers: The passage does not make a generalization about whether countries should sign nor whether they should consider other countries' economies as well as their own.

The passage states the economic minister's concern of the reduction in growth of the economy of their own country as being the primary reason for their country specifically to not sign, despite the positive effect of reducing the world's oceans' pollution.

Mice colonizing on an island that it too bleak and harsh to support human life supports the prediction that mice would be able to adapt and survive  in an environment too extreme to support human life.
Whether or not it is proven that mice inhabited North America prior to the arrival of humans has no bearing upon the passage as it focuses more on the future than it does the past.
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, would most support the naturalists' prediction?
main_answers: Fossil remains prove that mice inhabited North America prior to the arrival of humans.
Mice have colonized an island near Antarctica which is too bleak and harsh to support human life.
Under optimum conditions, mice reproduce every four weeks, with five to seven pups per litter.
The size of the mouse population is limited by the availability of food.

context: In a poll of a representative sample of a province' s residents, the provincial capital was the city most often selected as the best place to live in that province. Since the capital is also the largest of that province' s many cities, the poll shows that most residents of that province generally prefer life in large cities to life in small cities.
question: Why is the argument not considered to be flawed for overlooking the possibility that what is true of the residents of the province may not be true of other people?
answers: The poll specifically asked respondents what is the best place to live in the province and not for their preferences among cities.
If there was a significant amount of respondents who did not like the capital city due to its capital status, it would not have been most often selected in the poll.
The conclusion of the poll specifically referred to residents of that province and did not generalize its findings to all people.

Without a breakdown of the poll's results, it would be possible to conclude that the provincial city received the majority of the votes rather than the plurality of the votes, overestimating respondents' preference.
label: C

others.main_question: The argument is most vulnerable to the criticism that it
main_answers: overlooks the possibility that what is true of the residents of the province may not be true of other people
overlooks the possibility that most people may have voted for small cities even though a large city received more votes than any other single city
takes for granted that when people are polled for their preferences among cities, they tend to vote for the city that they think is the best place to live

overlooks the possibility that the people who preferred small cities over the provincial capital did so not because of their general feelings about the sizes of cities, but because of their general feelings about capital cities
others.target_option: overlooks the possibility that what is true of the residents of the province may not be true of other people

context: The highest mountain ranges are formed by geological forces that raise the earth' s crust: two continent-bearing tectonic plates of comparable density collide and crumple upward, causing a thickening of the crust. The erosive forces of wind and precipitation inexorably wear these mountains down. Yet the highest mountain ranges tend to be found in places where these erosive forces are most prevalent.
question: How does the fact that patterns of extreme wind and precipitation often result from the dramatic differences in elevation commonly found in the highest mountain ranges help to reconcile the apparent conflict described above?
answers: Vulnerability to predators would provide a valid reason for birds to have avoided visiting feeders, and could explain the reduced frequency of visits even if birds were numerous due to the mild conditions, as those conditions would also yielded an increased natural food supply for them.

If extreme wind and precipitation is an effect of the difference in elevation from the highest mountain ranges, then the highest mountain ranges would be more likely to contain those erosive forces and cause them to be more prevalent the more difference in elevation.
The process by which the differently elevated mountain ranges are formed should not affect how wind and precipitation wear down all mountain ranges.
If non-migrating birds exhausted their food supply, we would actually expect to see an increase in visits to feeders, rather than what was actually observed.
label: B

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to reconcile the apparent conflict described above?
main_answers: Patterns of extreme wind and precipitation often result from the dramatic differences in elevation commonly found in the highest mountain ranges.
Some lower mountain ranges are formed by a different collision process, whereby one tectonic plate simply slides beneath another of lesser density.
The amount of precipitation that a given region of the earth receives may vary considerably over the lifetime of an average mountain range.
The highest mountain ranges have less erosion-reducing vegetation near their peaks than do other mountain ranges.
others.target_option: Patterns of extreme wind and precipitation often result from the dramatic differences in elevation commonly found in the highest mountain ranges.

question: Explain why the fact that some lower mountain ranges are formed by a different collision process, whereby one tectonic plate simply slides beneath another of lesser density, does not help to reconcile the apparent conflict described above.
answers: If non-migrating birds exhausted their food supply, we would actually expect to see an increase in visits to feeders, rather than what was actually observed.

If extreme wind and precipitation is an effect of the difference in elevation from the highest mountain ranges, then the highest mountain ranges would be more likely to contain those erosive forces and cause them to be more prevalent the more difference in elevation.
The process by which the differently elevated mountain ranges are formed should not affect how wind and precipitation wear down all mountain ranges.

Vulnerability to predators would provide a valid reason for birds to have avoided visiting feeders, and could explain the reduced frequency of visits even if birds were numerous due to the mild conditions, as those conditions would also yielded an increased natural food supply for them.
label: C

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to reconcile the apparent conflict described above?
main_answers: Patterns of extreme wind and precipitation often result from the dramatic differences in elevation commonly found in the highest mountain ranges.
Some lower mountain ranges are formed by a different collision process, whereby one tectonic plate simply slides beneath another of lesser density.
The amount of precipitation that a given region of the earth receives may vary considerably over the lifetime of an average mountain range.
The highest mountain ranges have less erosion-reducing vegetation near their peaks than do other mountain ranges.
others.target_option: Some lower mountain ranges are formed by a different collision process, whereby one tectonic plate simply slides beneath another of lesser density.

context: The highest mountain ranges are formed by geological forces that raise the earth' s crust: two continent-bearing tectonic plates of comparable density collide and crumple upward, causing a thickening of the crust. The erosive forces of wind and precipitation inexorably wear these mountains down. Yet the highest mountain ranges tend to be found in places where these erosive forces are most prevalent.
question: How does the fact that the amount of precipitation that a given region of the earth receives may vary considerably over the lifetime of an average mountain range help to reconcile the apparent conflict described above?
answers: The highest mountain ranges are not necessarily concentrated in a region of Earth that has a considerably smaller amount of precipitation.
If a commensals is a bacteria that benefits a human being and M. tuberculosis has no benefit to a human being than it can be assumed that it can not be called a commensal.
Even if the higher mountain ranges have less vegetation to reduce erosion, that should only impact the rate of erosion itself, not the prevalence of wind and precipitation.
None of the above choices
label: D

context: For years the beautiful Renaissance buildings in Palitito have been damaged by exhaust from the many tour buses that come to the city. There has been little parking space, so most buses have idled at the curb during each stop on their tour, and idling produces as much exhaust as driving. The city has now provided parking that accommodates a third of the tour buses, so damage to Palitito' s buildings from the buses' exhaust will diminish significantly.
question: How does the fact that tour buses typically spend less than one-quarter of the time they are in Palitito transporting passengers from one site to another strongly support the argument?
answers: Some of the tour buses that are unable to find parking driving around Palitito would be a counter to the argument for establishing parking rather than supporting it.

If only one-quarter of the time buses are Palitito were spent transporting passengers then a great amount of time that was previously spent idling and producing exhaust will now be spend parked and not damaging buildings.
If exhaust from Palitito's few automobiles is not a significant threat to Palitito's buildings this would contradict the argument for addressing pollution caused by buses, not support it.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most strongly supports the argument?
main_answers: Tour buses typically spend less than one-quarter of the time they are in Palitito transporting passengers from one site to another.
Palitito's Renaissance buildings are not threatened by pollution other than engine exhaust.
The exhaust from Palitito's few automobiles is not a significant threat to Palitito's buildings.
Some of the tour buses that are unable to find parking drive around Palitito while their passengers are visiting a site.
others.target_option: Tour buses typically spend less than one-quarter of the time they are in Palitito transporting passengers from one site to another.

context: Adults have the right to vote; so should adolescents. Admittedly, adolescents and adults are not the same. But to the extent that adolescents and adults are different, adults cannot be expected to represent the interests of adolescents. If adults cannot represent the interests of adolescents, then only by giving adolescents the vote will these interests be represented.
question: Why does the argument not rely on the assumption that the right to vote is a right that all human beings should have?
answers: The argument does not rely on differences in the amount or importance of aspects.
The voting age is currently 18 but the legal drinking age is 21 in the overwhelming majority of states, so that would be an invalid assumption.
Without the assumption that adolescents are old enough to have their interests represented in politics the argument that they should be given the right to vote becomes meaningless.
The argument does not include pre-adolescent humans.
label: D

others.main_question: The argument relies on which one of the following assumptions?
main_answers: The right to vote is a right that all human beings should have.
Adolescents and adults differ in most respects that are important.
Adolescents should have their interests represented.
Anyone who has the right to vote has all the rights an adult has.
others.target_option: The right to vote is a right that all human beings should have.

context: The more worried investors are about losing their money, the more they will demand a high potential return on their investment: great risks must be offset by the chance of great rewards. This principle is the fundamental one in determining interest rates, and it is illustrated by the fact that __ .
question: What is the evidence that supports the claim that, in times of high inflation, the interest paid to depositors by banks can actually be below the rate of inflation?
answers: A single interest rate regardless of level of risk would actually undermine the link between risk and reward proposed in the passage.
Interest below the rate of inflation would represent a net loss to any investor, and so is not an example of a "great reward" which the passage argues is necessary.
As unsecured loans are inherently riskier than loans backed by collateral, the offering of greater rewards in the form of higher interest demonstrates the principle described in the passage.
If investors are not worried about their money, then offering great rewards would have no effect on their propensity to invest.
label: B

successful investors are distinguished by an ability to make very risky investments without worrying about their money

at any one time, a commercial bank will have a single rate of interest that it will expect all of its individual borrowers to pay

context: Kennel club members who frequently discipline their dogs report a higher incidence of misbehavior than do members who rarely or never discipline their dogs. We can conclude from this that discipline does not improve dogs' behavior; on the contrary, it encourages misbehavior.
question: What is the rationale for why the argument is flawed for failing to consider the possibility that dogs' misbehavior is the cause of, rather than the result of, frequent discipline?
answers: Dog's learning from previous discipline might actually be expected to improve their behaviour, which would generate a behaviour effect different to the one which is actually seen in practice.

The argument does not address the nature of the causal relationship between frequent discipline administration and poor dog behavior, instead making an unwarranted assumption that the former causes the latter.
The argument concerns only the effects of differing levels of discipline frequency, and does not draw conclusions about to the overall skill of the dog trainer.
None of the above choices
label: B

others.main_question: The argument is flawed in that it fails to consider the possibility that
main_answers: kennel club members are more likely to use discipline than are other dog owners
dogs' misbehavior is the cause of, rather than the result of, frequent discipline
dogs learn from past experience how their owners are likely to react to misbehavior
kennel club members tend to be more skilled at raising dogs than are other dog owners
others.target_option: dogs' misbehavior is the cause of, rather than the result of, frequent discipline

context: Thyrian lawmaker: Thyria's Cheese Importation Board inspects all cheese shipments to Thyria and rejects shipments not meeting specified standards. Yet only 1 percent is ever rejected. Ttherefore, since the health consequences and associated economic costs of not rejecting that 1 percent are negligible, whereas the board's operating costs are considerable, for economic reasons alone the board should be disbanded. Consultant: I disagree. The threat of having their shipments rejected deters many cheese exporters from shipping substandard product.
question: What benefit of maintaining the board does the consultant point out in response to the lawmaker's argument that the lawmaker's argument has failed to consider?
answers: The lawmaker only considered the benefits of rejecting the one percent of shipments and not other benefits such as determent of shipping substandard products.
It is not necessary to raise the standards for inspection in order to threaten the cheese exporters with having their shipments rejected.
Implying that cheese exporters might ship substandard product if not for the inspectors is not an attack on their integrity.
The lawmaker states that the board should be disbanded for economic reasons alone, as the costs as substantial.
label: A

others.main_question: The consultant responds to the lawmaker's argument by __.
main_answers: pointing out a benefi t of maintaining the board, which the lawmaker's argument has failed to consider
objecting to the lawmaker's introducing into the discussion factors that are not strictly economic
shifting the discussion from the argument at hand to an attack on the integrity of the cheese inspectors
rejecting the lawmaker's argument while proposing that the standards according to which the board inspects imported cheese should be raised
others.target_option: pointing out a benefi t of maintaining the board, which the lawmaker's argument has failed to consider

context: Thirty years ago, the percentage of the British people who vacationed in foreign countries was very small compared with the large percentage of the British population who travel abroad for vacations now. Foreign travel is, and always has been, expensive from Britain. Ttherefore, British people must have, on average, more money to spend on vacations now than they did 30 years ago.
question: Why does the argument not require assuming that if foreign travel had been less expensive 30 years ago, British people would still not have had enough money to take vacations abroad?
answers: We cannot assume that less expensive travel 30 years ago would have still prevented British people from having the money to travel and in fact can assume the opposite.
the strength of the argument doesn't rely on who is doing the mediating, only on when it is occurring

None of the above choices
label: A

context: G: The group of works exhibited in this year' s Metropolitan Art Show reveals a bias in favor of photographers. Equal numbers of photographers, sculptors, and painters submitted works that met the traditional criteria for the show, yet more photographs were exhibited than either sculptures or paintings. As you know, each artist was allowed to submit work in one medium only. H: How could there have been bias? All submitted works that met the traditional criteria -- and only those works -- were exhibited in the show.
question: What evidence supports the claim that more works that met the traditional criteria for the Metropolitan Art Show were submitted by photographers than by sculptors or painters?
answers: If an equal number of media met the criteria for the show, the show should have exhibited an equal number of media.

context: Country X contains many rivers that flow down from its high mountains. These rivers have been dammed to harness the hydroelectric power that can be derived from this resource. Enough power is generated to create a reserve that is more than enough to meet the country' s year-round energy needs. Yet, citizens of Country X often experience power shortages or even outages.
question: What is the evidence that the situation described above is not explained by the fact that the flow of the rivers is heavier in the spring than at other times of year?
answers: The passage says that the power generated is enough to power the entire country all year.
Whether some rivers are damned would not change anything in the passage.
If the power is sold to another country, then it is possible the locals would experience shortages or outages.
None of the above choices
label: A

Some of the most powerful rivers in Country X have yet to be dammed.

context: A senator, near the end of his first six-year term and running for reelection, made the claim: "Citizens of our state are thriving. While national unemployment levels have remained high, our state unemployment rate has been at astonishingly low levels for eleven years running. Clearly, everyone in our state has benefitted from the economical packages I have introduced during my time in the Senate. Ttherefore, grateful citizens of our state ought to vote for my second term. "
question: Why is it not valid to criticize the argument on the basis that the economical packages introduced by the senator may not have been as beneficial to citizens of other states?
answers: The citizens of the Senator's state are more concerned with how his policies affect them, than those of other states.
The unemployment rate of the state had been low for eleven years, while the Senator had only been in office for six. So he is taking credit for something that started before he was in office.
It would be in his self-interest to have the voters believe that he would keep their unemployment rates low.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: This argument is most vulnerable to what criticism?
main_answers: The economical packages introduced by the senator may not have been as beneficial to citizens of other states.
It takes a condition to be the effect of something that has happened only after the condition already existed.
It introduces several different types of evidence, not all of which are compatible with one another.
Even if what the senator is saying is true, it may not be in his self-interest to argue in favor of it.
others.target_option: The economical packages introduced by the senator may not have been as beneficial to citizens of other states.

context: By examining fossilized beetles, a research team has produced the most detailed description yet of temperatures in Britain over the past 22, 000 years. Fossils of species that still exist were selected and dated. When individuals of several species found in the same place were found to date to the same period, the known temperature tolerances of the existing beetle species were used to determine the maximum summer temperature that could have existed at that place and period.
question: What is the basis for the researchers assuming that the temperature tolerances of the beetle species did not change significantly during the 22,000-year period?
answers: If the species were found in the same place but in different periods it would not be possible to make a conclusion about the temperature tolerance since it could change between periods.
The ability to date beetles in comparison to other organisms is not essential since other items within the same strata of the fossil layer such as plants can also be used in dating.
The tolerance of beetles in cold weather is irrelevant since the researchers were looking to determine the maximum summer temperature of the place and period they studied.

Since current extant species of beetles were used as a benchmark for temperature tolerance, it would not be possible to make a like-for-like comparison to older instances of the same species if their temperature tolerance was much higher or lower.
label: D

others.main_question: The procedure of the researchers assumes which one of the following?
main_answers: The temperature tolerances of the beetle species did not change significantly during the 22, 000-year period.
Beetles can tolerate warm weather better than cold weather.
The process of dating is more accurate for beetles than for other organisms.
Fossils of different species found in the same place belonged to different period.
others.target_option: The temperature tolerances of the beetle species did not change significantly during the 22, 000-year period.

context: Although this bottle is labeled "vinegar, " no fizzing occurred when some of the liquid in it was added to powder from this box labeled "baking soda. " But when an acidic liquid such as vinegar is added to baking soda the resulting mixture fizzes, so this bottle clearly has been mislabeled.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument not considered to be flawed due to its reliance on the imprecise term "fizz"?
answers: Very basic chemical reactions such as the one described don't need to be tested in some pristine laboratory, such things are meant to occur always so long as the correct chemicals are mixed.
There can be other explanations for the effect, such as either of the ingredients being tainted or the baking soda and not the vinegar being mislabeled.
The passage does not state that there was any deception involved in the mislabeling, it's entirely possible the mislabeling was an honest mistake.
While the term "fizz" isn't entirely an incredibly precise and scientific term, it is clear enough that a complete lack of fizz is something most people can comprehend.
label: D

others.main_question: A flaw in the reasoning in the argument above is that this argument
main_answers: depends on the use of the imprecise term "fizz"
assumes that the fact of a labeling error is proof of an intention to deceive
fails to exclude an alternative explanation for the observed effect
does not take into account the fact that scientific principles can be definitively tested only under controlled laboratory conditions
others.target_option: depends on the use of the imprecise term "fizz"

context: Although this bottle is labeled "vinegar, " no fizzing occurred when some of the liquid in it was added to powder from this box labeled "baking soda. " But when an acidic liquid such as vinegar is added to baking soda the resulting mixture fizzes, so this bottle clearly has been mislabeled.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument not considered to be flawed for not taking into account the fact that scientific principles can be definitively tested only under controlled laboratory conditions?
answers: Very basic chemical reactions such as the one described don't need to be tested in some pristine laboratory, such things are meant to occur always so long as the correct chemicals are mixed.
While the term "fizz" isn't entirely an incredibly precise and scientific term, it is clear enough that a complete lack of fizz is something most people can comprehend.
The passage does not state that there was any deception involved in the mislabeling, it's entirely possible the mislabeling was an honest mistake.
There can be other explanations for the effect, such as either of the ingredients being tainted or the baking soda and not the vinegar being mislabeled.
label: A

others.main_question: A flaw in the reasoning in the argument above is that this argument
main_answers: depends on the use of the imprecise term "fizz"
assumes that the fact of a labeling error is proof of an intention to deceive
fails to exclude an alternative explanation for the observed effect
does not take into account the fact that scientific principles can be definitively tested only under controlled laboratory conditions
others.target_option: does not take into account the fact that scientific principles can be definitively tested only under controlled laboratory conditions

context: In the past, most children who went sledding in the winter snow in Verland used wooden sleds with runners and steering bars. Ten years ago, smooth plastic sleds became popular; they go faster than wooden sleds but are harder to steer and slow. The concern that plastic sleds are more dangerous is clearly borne out by the fact that the number of children injured while sledding was much higher last winter than it was ten years ago.
question: Explain why the fact that a few children still use traditional wooden sleds does not seriously undermine the force of the evidence cited in Verland?
answers: If most injuries occur when colliding with objects, then it would only strengthen the argument that plastic sleds are more dangerous given they are harder to steer and thus harder to avoid collisions with.

If plastic sleds are usable in more conditions, then it's possible that it's not the sleds themselves that are more dangerous, but the increase in sledding itself which logically links to an increase in injuries.
If a few children still use traditional wooden sleds, this would not undermine the link between the growing popularity of plastic sleds and the increase in injuries.

There is no reason to assume the lack of protective gear is specific to people using plastic sleds, so it would not explain the increase in injuries over the years that plastic sleds became more popular.
label: C

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true in Verland, most seriously undermines the force of the evidence cited?
main_answers: A few children still use traditional wooden sleds.
Plastic sleds can be used in a much wider variety of snow conditions than wooden sleds can.
Most sledding injuries occur when a sled collides with a tree, a rock, or, another sled.
Very few children wear any kind of protective gear, such as helmets, while sledding.
others.target_option: A few children still use traditional wooden sleds.

context: On average, corporations that encourage frequent social events in the workplace show higher profits than those that rarely do. This suggests that the EZ Corporation could boost its profits by having more staff parties during business hours.
question: Explain why the fact that frequent social events in a corporate workplace leave employees with less time to perform their assigned duties than they would otherwise have does not weaken the argument.
answers: Frequent social events in a corporate workplace can re-energize employees, like a lunch break does.
The timing of the social event in the day may or may not have a bearing on its effects.
If a corporation is earning less-than-average profits, frequent social events in the workplace would interfere with needed productivity.
None of the above choices
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most weakens the argument above?
main_answers: Frequent social events in a corporate workplace leave employees with less time to perform their assigned duties than they would otherwise have.
The great majority of corporations that encourage frequent social events in the workplace do so at least in part because they are already earning above-average profits.
The EZ Corporation already earns above average profits, and it almost never brings play into the workplace.
Corporations that have frequent staff parties after business hours sometimes have higher profits than do corporations that have frequent staff parties during business hours.
others.target_option: Frequent social events in a corporate workplace leave employees with less time to perform their assigned duties than they would otherwise have.

context: Along the mudflats of Garantia exist two types of annelids: earthworms and lugworms. Earthworms tend to emerge from the mud early in the morning when there is more moisture and nutrients. As a result, earthworms have access to more nutrients and thus reproduce far faster than the lugworm, which spends much of the day submerged in the mud. Nonetheless, the lugworm population far outnumbers that of the earthworm.
question: How does the fact that lugworms have specialized taste receivers, which allow them to access nutrients below ground far more easily than earthworms can, help least to resolve the apparent discrepancy noted above?
answers: If the whooping crane hunts mainly during times that the earthworms are feeding at the surface, that would only decrease the population of the earthworms, but not less than what they would have from not feeding at the surface and not increase the lugworms population at all.

If lugworms are able to access nutrients below ground more easily then earthworms can, then it's possible for the lugworm to actually reproduce more than previously thought and increase their population.
The businessman states that sales is the most important part of any business and that every other department other than sales should be eliminated.
While this is true, it is again more of a common knowledge that businesses have multiple departments and not vital to the businessman's argument.
label: B

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, helps LEAST to resolve the apparent discrepancy noted above?
main_answers: Lugworms have specialized taste receivers, which allow them to access nutrients below ground far more easily than earthworms can.
The whooping crane, the earthworm's chief predator, hunts along the mudflats during the time the earthworms are feeding at the surface.
Compared to the lugworm, earthworms are able to consume fewer nutrients at one time.
Lugworms resemble the color of the mudflat, and are thus more difficult to spot by predators than earthworms are.
others.target_option: Lugworms have specialized taste receivers, which allow them to access nutrients below ground far more easily than earthworms can.

context: Commentator: The quality of health care is declining. Medical schools have been graduating fewer people than are needed to replace retiring physicians. Furthermore, on average, a physician now spends only 15 minutes with a patient on the patient' s first visit.
question: Why does the fact that most patients visiting a physician are suffering from ailments that are not life threatening not weaken the commentator's argument?
answers: If the average time five years ago was 10 minutes and the current time that a physican spends is around 15 minutes than it can be assumed that the doctor does not spend much time with a patient on the intial visit and that has not changed much in the last five years.
The auther is focusing on the amount of time spent vs why they are there.
Every patient is different and the needs of each patient and desire to be there will vary greatly.
The author is assuming that the quality has gone down so it would need to have previously times to comparte it with.
label: B

Most patients do not like to spend an inordinate amount of time in physicians' offices.
Five years ago, the average first patient-physician visit lasted 10 minutes.

context: A clothing manufacturer reports that unsalable garments, those found to be defective by inspectors plus those returned by retailers, total 7 percent of the garments produced. Further, it reports that all of its unsalable garments are recycled as scrap, but the percentage of garments reported as recycled scrap is 9 percent.
question: Why does the fact that the total number of garments produced by the manufacturer has increased slightly over the past year not contribute to explaining the discrepancy between the reported percentages?
answers: If the overall number of produced garments is up, the number of recycled garments would also likely be up.
If different methods are being used in regards to tracking recycled items, the number may not be as accurate since there could be different levels of accuracy between weighing and counting garments.
Garments with defects not being recycled would cause the number of recycled items to be lower rather than higher.
Defects being reported would not necessarily increase the number of recycled scrap since not all may be recycled and those being mislabeled as defective would not necessarily be recycled.
label: A

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, could contribute most to explaining the discrepancy between the reported percentages?
main_answers: The total number of garments produced by the manufacturer has increased slightly over the past year.
Some inspectors, in order to appear more efficient, tend to overreport defects.
Garments with minor blemishes are sent to wholesale outlets for sale at discounted prices and are not returned for recycling.
Insalable garments are recorded by count, but recycled garments are recorded by weight.
others.target_option: The total number of garments produced by the manufacturer has increased slightly over the past year.

context: Half a dozen Q40 airliners have crashed in the past two years. The manufacturer has countered claims that the Q40' s design is faulty by pointing out that, in each of the accidents, investigations indicated pilot error as the cause.
question: Explain why the fact that one of the crashes occurred in very poor visibility when the pilot was attempting to land does not provide the strongest support for the manufacturer's position.
answers: If the majority of the crashes were caused by such egregious pilot error, then it provides support for there being nothing wrong with the planes.
A crash at night could be pilot error, but it could also be a problem in the equipment the pilot relied on for poor night visibility.
If this was true, then pilot error shouldn't have caused a crash and that it was at least partially an issue with the plane.
Some of those other factors could have been due to poor design or manufacture.
label: B

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, provides the strongest support for the manufacturer's position?
main_answers: One of the crashes occurred in very poor visibility when the pilot was attempting to land.
In four of the crashes, the pilot's error involved disregarding instructions or information supplied by air-traffic control
Each of the investigations identified several factors other than pilot error as subsidiary causes.
Like most modern airliners, the Q40 was designed with the goal that it should be highly tolerant of pilot error.
others.target_option: One of the crashes occurred in very poor visibility when the pilot was attempting to land.

context: People who object to the proposed hazardous waste storage site by appealing to extremely implausible scenarios in which the site fails to contain the waste safely are overlooking the significant risks associated with delays in moving the waste from its present unsafe location. If we wait to remove the waste until we find a site certain to contain it safely, the waste will remain in its current location for many years, since it is currently impossible to guarantee that any site can meet that criterion. Yet keeping the waste at the current location for that long clearly poses unacceptable risks.
question: Why does the fact that the statements above strongly support the waste being placed in the most secure location that can ever be found not necessarily follow?
answers: The author wants the waste moved immediately, even if the ideal location hasn’t been found.
The threat in leaving the waste at the current location must be a greater danger than the danger posed by putting it in a new location.

context: The habit many students on today' s campuses have of scribbling in their textbooks is inexcusable. It is harmful to books, aesthetically displeasing, and distracting to readers who buy the textbooks used.
question: Why does the fact that many students do not scribble in their textbooks not weaken the argument?
answers: It doesn't matter if many students don't scribble so long as there are still many students who do.
Even if something is not illegal it may still be inexcusable.

context: Secondary school students achieve broad mastery of the curriculum if they are taught with methods appropriate to their learning styles and they devote significant effort to their studies. Thus, if such broad mastery is not achieved by the students in a particular secondary school, those students are not being taught with methods appropriate to their learning styles.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that the conclusion can be properly drawn if it is assumed that even if secondary school students are taught with methods appropriate to their learning styles, they will not achieve broad mastery of the curriculum if they do not devote significant effort to their studies?
answers: Significant effort to their studies is stated as a condition for broad mastery and since only methods were mentioned in the conclusion, it must be assumed that they will devote significant effort if taught with methods appropriate to their learning style.
This is restating the conclusion.
The conclusion is concerning method of being taught and although true, it is not necessary to assume this without its connection to the method.
None of the above choices
label: A

context: Besides laying eggs in her own nest, any female wood duck will lay an egg in the nest of another female wood duck if she sees the other duck leaving her nest. Under natural nesting conditions, this parasitic behavior is relatively rare because the ducks' nests are well hidden. However, when people put up nesting boxes to help the ducks breed, they actually undercut the ducks' reproductive efforts. These nesting boxes become so crowded with extra eggs that few, if any, of the eggs in those boxes hatch.
question: What is the reason for why the statements do not strongly support the claim that the nesting boxes for wood ducks have less space for eggs than do natural nesting sites?
answers: The passage does not say if wood ducks with female companions produce more eggs or not.
The sizes of the nesting boxes or natural nests are not mentioned in the passage.
The passage does not indicate if wood ducks prefer nests or nest boxes.
The passage indicates that because the nest boxes are obvious, that more eggs are laid in them causing them not to hatch.
label: B

others.main_question: The statements above, if true, most strongly support which one of the following?
main_answers: The nesting boxes for wood ducks have less space for eggs than do natural nesting sites.
Female wood ducks will establish nests in nest boxes only when natural nesting sites are not available.
Nesting female wood ducks who often see other female wood ducks are the most successful in their breeding efforts.
The nesting boxes would be more effective in helping wood ducks breed if they were less visible to other wood ducks than they currently are.
others.target_option: The nesting boxes for wood ducks have less space for eggs than do natural nesting sites.

context: Philosopher: Both the consequences and the motives of human actions have bearing on the moral worth of those actions. Nonetheless, to be a moral agent one must have free will, because one cannot be a moral agent without desiring to conform to a principle.
question: What evidence is there to suggest that the philosopher's argument does not depend on the assumption that nobody who acts without taking the consequences of the action into consideration is free?
answers: Moral agency requiring conformation to a principle regarding its likely effects is stated explicitly in the argument, and is not an assumption made by it.
Acting thoughtlessly and amorally can still be done freely, as the assumption of the necessity of freedom made in the passage only concerns moral actions.
The argument concerns only one specific type of desire, not desires in general.
If moral actions require confirmation to a principle, if follows that if a desire for such confirmation requires free will then so will the moral actions that result from it.
label: B
