It is more important to maintain economic growth in one's own country than it is to reduce pollution in the world's oceans.
others.target_option: If a policy is likely to protect the environment and is unlikely to reduce economic growth, then governments should implement that policy.

context: Forty to 60 percent of students report, in anonymous surveys, that they plagiarized at least once as undergraduates, and evidence indicates that plagiarism also occurs in our medical and business schools. Researchers have found that students who plagiarize are more likely to engage in subsequent professional misconduct such as falsified research results and fraudulent business practices. Thus, a reduction of academic plagiarism will lead to a reduction of professional misconduct.
question: Explain why the argument does not have a flaw as accurately described by the fact that it presumes, without providing justification, that a certain phenomenon is the only factor contributing to the incidence of a certain other phenomenon?
answers: The brain making less dopamine in those with Parkinson's supports the idea that the lack of dopamine causes the medical issue.
Professional misconduct can be performed by people who did not plagiarize as an undergraduate.
Other chemicals affecting the brain does not reduce the possibility that dopamine causes Parkinson's.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following most accurately describes a flaw in the reasoning in the argument?
main_answers: The argument presumes, without providing justification, that a certain phenomenon is the only factor contributing to the incidence of a certain other phenomenon.
The argument infers the existence of a causal connection merely on the basis of an association.
The argument takes for granted that a certain behavior is more prevalent among members of one population than it is among members of another.
The argument introduces one subject for debate, but proceeds to give premises relevant to a different subject.
others.target_option: The argument presumes, without providing justification, that a certain phenomenon is the only factor contributing to the incidence of a certain other phenomenon.

context: In an experiment, researchers played a series of musical intervals -- two-note sequences -- to a large, diverse group of six-month-old babies. They found that the babies paid significantly more attention when the intervals were perfect octaves, fifths, or fourths than otherwise. These intervals are prevalent in the musical systems of most cultures around the world. Thus, humans probably have a biological predisposition to pay more attention to those intervals than to others.
question: Explain why the fact that octaves, fifths, and fourths were played more frequently during the experiment than other musical intervals were does not strengthen the argument.
answers: This strengthens the argument because without this requirement environmental causation cannot be ruled out.
Such exposure to the environment of world music, which mostly favors two-note intervals, makes the biological predisposition argument invalid.
It is impossible to rule out the cultural or environmental influence in older children and adults.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the argument?
main_answers: Octaves, fifths, and fourths were played more frequently during the experiment than other musical intervals were.

Several similar experiments using older children and adults found that these subjects, too, had a general tendency to pay more attention to octaves, fifths, and fourths than to other musical intervals.
All of the babies in the experiment had been exposed to music drawn equally from a wide variety of cultures around the world.
None of the babies in the experiment had previous exposure to music from any culture.
others.target_option: Octaves, fifths, and fourths were played more frequently during the experiment than other musical intervals were.

context: A hardware store generally sells roughly equal numbers of Maxlast brand hammers and Styron brand hammers. Last week, all of the Maxlast hammers were put on sale and placed in a display case just inside the store entrance while the Styron hammers retained their usual price and location. Surprisingly, the Styron hammers slightly outsold the Maxlast hammers.
question: What is the reason for the surprising result not being explained by the fact that customers who bought the Maxlast hammers last week commonly mentioned the sale as their reason for buying a hammer at that time?
answers: If the Maxlast hammers were being promoted in flyers, one would expect them to be more popular than the Styron hammers which weren't promoted.
One would expect that the customers would walk right by the Maxlast hammers as they immediately entered the store and not see the promotional display.
One would still expect those shoppers that were in the store already to buy the cheaper hammer.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, does most to explain the surprising result?
main_answers: Customers who bought the Maxlast hammers last week commonly mentioned the sale as their reason for buying a hammer at that time.
The hardware store circulated flyers that publicized the sale prices on Maxlast hammers.
For the first several seconds after shoppers enter a store, they do not take detailed notice of the store's merchandise.
In general, a single item that is on sale will not motivate shoppers to make a special trip to a store.
others.target_option: Customers who bought the Maxlast hammers last week commonly mentioned the sale as their reason for buying a hammer at that time.

context: Although most people know what their bad habits are and want to rid themselves of them, a majority of these people find it very difficult to do so. This is because cessation of habitual behavior is immediately and vividly painful, while whatever benefit is to be gained by the absence of the habit is perceived only dimly because it is remote.
question: What evidence supports the statement that the people who are successful at ending their bad habits are those who can vividly imagine remote but attainable benefit?
answers: Imagining the current pain continuing into the future is defeatism, which is the opposite of motivation.
Someone who is unaware of their own bad habits is not likely to want to change them.
Modifying behavior is not quite the same as completely ending a bad behavioral characteristic.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The information above most strongly supports the statement that the people who are most successful at ending their bad habits are those who
main_answers: have succeeded in the past at modifying their behavior
can vividly imagine remote but attainable benefit
can vividly imagine their present pain being felt in the future
are relatively unaware of their own behavioral characteristics
others.target_option: can vividly imagine remote but attainable benefit

context: Statistics from the National Booksellers Association indicate that during the last five years most bookstores have started to experience declining revenues from the sale of fiction, despite national campaigns to encourage people to read more fiction. Ttherefore, these reading campaigns have been largely unsuccessful.
question: Explain why the fact that due to the poor economic conditions that have prevailed during the last five years, most libraries report substantial increases in the number of patrons seeking books on changing careers and starting new businesses does not weaken the argument?
answers: The substantial growth in mail order fiction sales could be more than the decline in bookstore sales, thus the campaign would not be unsuccessful.
Understanding the methods has no bearing on which methods works best.
The variability of the plants is not addressed but rather the viability.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following statements, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
main_answers: The National Booksellers Association statistics do not include profits from selling novels by mail to overseas customers.
During the last five years the most profitable items in bookstores have been newspapers and periodicals rather than novels.

Due to the poor economic conditions that have prevailed during the last five years, most libraries report substantial increases in the number of patrons seeking books on changing careers and starting new businesses.
Mail order book clubs have enjoyed substantial growth in fiction sales throughout the last five years.
others.target_option: Due to the poor economic conditions that have prevailed during the last five years, most libraries report substantial increases in the number of patrons seeking books on changing careers and starting new businesses.

context: People should avoid taking the antacid calcium carbonate in doses larger than half a gram, for despite its capacity to neutralize stomach acids, calcium carbonate can increase the calcium level in the blood and thus impair kidney function. Moreover, just half a gram of it can stimulate the production of gastrin, a stomach hormone that triggers acid secretion.
question: Why is it not reasonable to conclude that people who avoid taking more than half a gram of calcium carbonate are less likely than average to suffer from impaired kidney function based on the information provided?
answers: The antacid reduces stomach acid in general and there is no mention of how effective each dose is at neutralizing acid.
That cannot be inferred from the passage because there could theoretically be many other forms of depression that can be treated more easily than baking and eating cookies.

That cannot be properly inferred because the passage only talks about increasing the level of serotonin in the brain. Lack of sunlight may leave the brain at a base level of serotonin rather than lower it.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the information above?
main_answers: Half a gram of calcium carbonate can causally contribute to both the secretion and the neutralization of stomach acids.
Impaired kidney function may increase the level of calcium in the blood.
People who avoid taking more than half a gram of calcium carbonate are less likely than average to suffer from impaired kidney function.
Doses of calcium carbonate smaller than half a gram can reduce stomach acid more effectively than much larger doses do.
others.target_option: People who avoid taking more than half a gram of calcium carbonate are less likely than average to suffer from impaired kidney function.

context: During its caterpillar stage, the leopard magpie moth feeds on a plant called the Natal grass cycad and by so doing laces its body with macrozamin, a toxin that makes the moth highly unpalatable to would-be predators. Since the Natal grass cycad is now endangered and facing extinction, the leopard magpie moth is also in danger of extinction.
question: Which of the following reasoning justifies that the argument does not require the assumption that the leopard magpie moth does not have the speed or the agility to escape from any of its potential predators?
answers: Since potential predators find the leopard magpie moth unpalatable, they are not able to consume them and build a tolerance.
If  the leopard magpie moth had other means of making itself unpalatable, there'd be no relation between either going extinct.
Potential predators find macrozamin unpalatable whether they can see it or not.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the argument?
main_answers: Potential predators of the leopard magpie moth cannot determine from appearance alone whether a moth's body is laced with macrozamin.
The leopard magpie moth does not have the speed or the agility to escape from any of its potential predators.
None of the potential predators of the leopard magpie moth have developed a tolerance to macrozamin.
Feeding on the Natal grass cycad is the only means by which the leopard magpie moth can make itself highly unpalatable to predators.
others.target_option: The leopard magpie moth does not have the speed or the agility to escape from any of its potential predators.

context: Despite the best efforts of astronomers, no one has yet succeeded in exchanging messages with intelligent life on other planets or in other solar systems. In fact, no one has even managed to prove that any kind of extraterrestrial life exists. Thus, there is clearly no intelligent life anywhere but on Earth.
question: Why is the argument's reasoning considered flawed for confusing an absence of evidence for a hypothesis with the existence of evidence against the hypothesis?
answers: The author is focusing solely on mathematics and how that can help keep a competitive edge in the global economy.
The author does not statet hat this will guarantee that it will be overcome but that it will make help make it possible.
No analogy of any kind is made during the argument.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The argument's reasoning is flawed because the argument
main_answers: relies on a weak analogy rather than on evidence to draw a conclusion
confuses an absence of evidence for a hypothesis with the existence of evidence against the hypothesis
makes an inference that relies on the vagueness of the term "life"
fails to consider that there might be extraterrestrial forms of intelligence that are not living beings
others.target_option: confuses an absence of evidence for a hypothesis with the existence of evidence against the hypothesis

context: Advertisement for a lactase supplement: Lactase, an enzyme produced by the body, aids in the digestion of lactose, a natural sugar found in dairy foods. Many subjects in an experiment who drank a liter of milk on an empty stomach showed signs of lactose intolerance -- difficulty in digesting dairy products because of insufficient lactase. Thus, extrapolating from the number of subjects adversely affected, at least 50 million people in North America alone should take lactase supplements.
question: Explain why the fact that some dairy foods, such as cheese, contain a form of lactose more difficult to digest than that found in milk does not seriously weaken the argument.
answers: If jokes do not conform to patterns but rather break them, then they would be more difficult to remember as the brains remembers best with repeated patterns.
Verbal or clearly symbolic content is also able to be presented in a form which includes melodic and rhythmic patterns similarly to music.
The effects of lactose on nutrition does not affect a person's tolerance for lactose.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following statements, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
main_answers: Lactose intolerance can interfere with proper nutrition.
Some dairy foods, such as cheese, contain a form of lactose more difficult to digest than that found in milk.
Most people who consume dairy products consume less lactose at each meal than the amount found in a liter of milk.
Eating solid food when drinking milk can decrease the amount of lactase produced by the body.
others.target_option: Some dairy foods, such as cheese, contain a form of lactose more difficult to digest than that found in milk.

context: Brand X, which currently markets luxury watches via billboards and advertisements in popular magazines, is considering saving money by advertising its newest line of luxury watches only in niche publications read by the wealthy. A recent study shows that most purchasers of Brand X's luxury watches have only recently become wealthy, and purchase the watches because Brand X is highly coveted by those aspiring to wealth, who learn about Brand X watches via advertising. Ttherefore, Brand X should not implement its new advertising strategy because __.
question: What is the reason for why the money saved by implementing the strategy will not be outweighed by the reduction in revenue from the less expensive line of watches?
answers: Taylor discounts coincidence, but does not argue against any other reasonable explanation.
If they preferred purchasing products used by the non-wealthy, they would not buy luxury watches that the poorer consumers could not afford.
Telepathy among friends and family doesn't exclude telepathy with strangers.

others.main_question: Which of the following best completes the passage below?
main_answers: the money saved by implementing the strategy will be outweighed by the reduction in revenue from the less expensive line of watches
consumers who are newly wealthy prefer to purchase products that are purchased regularly by the non-wealthy
newly rich consumers will not buy the watches if the watches are not advertised to people who are not yet wealthy who will then hold the watches in high regard
most purchasers of Brand X's luxury watches do not read magazines regularly

context: Having lived through extraordinary childhood circumstances, Robin has no conception of the moral difference between right and wrong, only between what is legally permitted and what is not. When Robin committed an offense, Robin did not recognize the fact that it was a morally wrong act, despite knowing that it was illegal.

others.main_question: From the statements above, which one of the following can be properly inferred?

Robin could now be brought to see the moral difference between right and wrong.
Robin's childhood could have provided more adequate moral training even in the circumstances.
Moral ignorance is never excusable in the eyes of the law.

context: The city of Workney, in raising bus fares from $1. 00 to $1. 25, proposed that 18 fare tokens be sold for $20. 00 to alleviate the extra burden of the fare increase on the city' s poor people. context: Journalist: Many people working on difficult problems in mathematics report going to sleep without a solution, but upon awaking discover they have a solution in mind. This phenomenon occurs among all age groups past infancy.

context: Adult frogs are vulnerable to dehydration because of their highly permeable skins. Unlike large adult frogs, small adult frogs have such a low ratio of body weight to skin surface area that they cannot survive in arid climates. The animals' moisture requirements constitute the most important factor determining where frogs can live in the Yucatan peninsula, which has an arid climate in the north and a wet climate in the south.

answers: As large adult frogs are less vulnerable to arid conditions, they would be more able to survive in varied climates across the area.

Quore's production structure is relevant to the fact that if a 10% increase is possible, then so is a 20% increase, not whether or not they can meet that 10% marker and survive the transformation of the market.
The passage states that if a 10% increase is possible, then a 20% increase is possible, it does not state whether that 10% increase will be met.
None of the above choices

others.main_question: The information above most strongly supports which one of the following conclusions about frogs in the Yucatan peninsula?

context: Someone who gets sick from eating a meal will often develop a strong distaste for the one food in the meal that had the most distinctive flavor, whether or not that food caused the sickness. This phenomenon explains why children are especially likely to develop strong aversions to some foods.
question: Why does the fact that children are less likely than adults to see a connection between their health and the foods they eat not provide the strongest support for the explanation?
answers: The justification used to state the causal relationship are the studies and insurance statistics.
Differences in the frequency of the two actions could produce different results if the number of overall deaths is higher, but the number of safe crossings is higher as well.
The variety of food someone eats has no bearing on whether or not they will get sick from food.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, provides the strongest support for the explanation?
main_answers: Children tend to have more acute taste and to become sick more often than adults do.
Children typically recover more slowly than adults do from sickness caused by food.
Children are more likely than are adults to refuse to eat unfamiliar foods.
Children are less likely than adults to see a connection between their health and the foods they eat.
others.target_option: Children are less likely than adults to see a connection between their health and the foods they eat.

context: Mayor: To keep our neighborhoods clean, every street in town will be swept at least once a month. If a neighborhood needs more frequent sweepings, due to excessive dirt from major construction for example, that neighborhood will be qualified for interim sweepings. All requests for interim sweepings from qualified neighborhoods will be satisfied immediately.
question: Why does it not follow that no street will be swept more than once a month unless it is located in a qualified neighborhood if the statement above is true?
answers: The conclusion pertains to the ice sheet, not the location of recently discovered remains.

We are not given this information in the passage and cannot simply assume that a neighborhood is qualified if it has construction occurring unless we are given information that excessive dirt is a result of the construction.
The author's conclusion is focused on the existence or extent of the ice sheet rather than the mechanism that may have caused changes in it.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: If all of the mayor's statements are true, then which one of the following must also be true?
main_answers: A qualified neighborhood that requests an interim sweeping will have its streets swept more than once a month.
All qualified neighborhoods will get their streets swept more than once a month.
No street will be swept more than once a month unless it is located in a qualified neighborhood.
All neighborhoods in which construction is under way are qualified neighborhoods.
others.target_option: No street will be swept more than once a month unless it is located in a qualified neighborhood.

context: Statistical records of crime rates probably often reflect as much about the motives and methods of those who compile or cite them as they do about the actual incidence of crime. The police may underreport crime in order to convey the impression of their own success or overreport crime to make the case for a budget increase. Politicians may magnify crime rates to get elected or minimize them to remain in office. Newspapers, of course, often sensationalize crime statistics to increase readership.
question: Why does the argument not proceed by enumerating problems for which it proposes a general solution?
answers: This passage is giving examples of a claim, not generalizing anything.
The passage starts out saying that crime rates really don't matter and proceeds to give reasons why they are misleading.
Nothing in this passage contradicts its conclusion.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The argument proceeds by doing which one of the following?
main_answers: deriving implications of a generalization that it assumes to be true
citing examples in support of its conclusion
enumerating problems for which it proposes a general solution
showing how evidence that apparently contradicts its conclusion actually supports that conclusion
others.target_option: enumerating problems for which it proposes a general solution

context: Manager: One reason productivity in our office is not as high as it could be is that office workers spend too much time taking unauthorized breaks. Since the number of office workers assigned to each manager will soon be reduced, managers will be able to supervise workers more closely in the future to make sure that they are not taking unauthorized breaks. Ttherefore, productivity in our office will soon increase.
question: Which of the following reasoning justifies that the manager's argument depends on the assumption that the gain in productivity that will result from reducing unauthorized breaks will exceed any loss in productivity caused by closer supervision?
answers: Reducing the number of employees and giving those who remain more work does not necessarily decrease the amount of unauthorized breaks those employees still take.
Even if reducing unauthorized breaks is not the most efficient way of increasing productivity, it is still possible for it to be one way to increase productivity.
No financial incentives are being given to workers whose divisions increase productivity.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the manager's argument depends?
main_answers: Supervising employees more closely to reduce unauthorized breaks is the most efficient way of increasing overall office productivity.
The gain in productivity that will result from reducing unauthorized breaks will exceed any loss in productivity caused by closer supervision.
Giving financial incentives to workers whose divisions increase their productivity would not have any significant effect on overall office productivity.
The best way to improve productivity is to reduce the number of employees and give more work to employees who remain on the job.
others.target_option: The gain in productivity that will result from reducing unauthorized breaks will exceed any loss in productivity caused by closer supervision.

context: For years the beautiful Renaissance buildings in Palitito have been damaged by exhaust from the many tour buses that come to the city. There has been little parking space, so most buses have idled at the curb during each stop on their tour, and idling produces as much exhaust as driving. The city has now provided parking that accommodates a third of the tour buses, so damage to Palitito' s buildings from the buses' exhaust will diminish significantly.
question: Explain why the fact that Palitito's Renaissance buildings are not threatened by pollution other than engine exhaust does not strongly support the argument.
answers: Some of the tour buses that are unable to find parking driving around Palitito would be a counter to the argument for establishing parking rather than supporting it.
If exhaust from Palitito's few automobiles is not a significant threat to Palitito's buildings this would contradict the argument for addressing pollution caused by buses, not support it.

If only one-quarter of the time buses are Palitito were spent transporting passengers then a great amount of time that was previously spent idling and producing exhaust will now be spend parked and not damaging buildings.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most strongly supports the argument?
main_answers: Tour buses typically spend less than one-quarter of the time they are in Palitito transporting passengers from one site to another.
Palitito's Renaissance buildings are not threatened by pollution other than engine exhaust.
The exhaust from Palitito's few automobiles is not a significant threat to Palitito's buildings.
Some of the tour buses that are unable to find parking drive around Palitito while their passengers are visiting a site.
others.target_option: Palitito's Renaissance buildings are not threatened by pollution other than engine exhaust.

context: Thirty years ago, the percentage of the British people who vacationed in foreign countries was very small compared with the large percentage of the British population who travel abroad for vacations now. Foreign travel is, and always has been, expensive from Britain. Ttherefore, British people must have, on average, more money to spend on vacations now than they did 30 years ago.
question: Why is it not necessary to assume that if British people are now wealthier than they were 30 years ago, then they must have more money to spend on vacations now than they did 30 years ago in order for the argument to be valid?
answers: The overall graduate application rate increasing would not explain the apparent discrepancy in the passage.
We are not given information regarding domestic vacations in the passage and cannot assume that British people were or were not spending a lot of money on it 30 years ago.
A change in the college's ranking would not explain why applications and admissions increased while class size remained unchanged.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The argument requires assuming which one of the following?
main_answers: If more of the British people of 30 years ago had had enough money to vacation abroad, more would have done so.
If foreign travel had been less expensive 30 years ago, British people would still not have had enough money to take vacations abroad.
If the percentage of British people vacationing abroad was lower 30 years ago, then the British people of 30 years ago must have spent more money on domestic vacations.
If British people are now wealthier than they were 30 years ago, then they must have more money to spend on vacations now than they did 30 years ago.
others.target_option: If British people are now wealthier than they were 30 years ago, then they must have more money to spend on vacations now than they did 30 years ago.

context: G: The group of works exhibited in this year' s Metropolitan Art Show reveals a bias in favor of photographers. Equal numbers of photographers, sculptors, and painters submitted works that met the traditional criteria for the show, yet more photographs were exhibited than either sculptures or paintings. As you know, each artist was allowed to submit work in one medium only. H: How could there have been bias? All submitted works that met the traditional criteria -- and only those works -- were exhibited in the show.
question: What evidence is there that the statement that some of the photographs submitted for the Metropolitan Art Show did not meet the traditional criteria for the show is not necessarily true?
answers: If passengers per flight remained unchanged then it would offer no explanation for an increase in frequency of complaints.
An equal number of photographers, sculptors and painters submitted works to be considered.
A change in the exact number of flights may not explain the uptick in complaints.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: If both G's assertions and H's assertion are true, which one of the following must also be true?
main_answers: Some of the photographs submitted for the Metropolitan Art Show did not meet the traditional criteria for the show.
More photographers than sculptors or painters submitted works to be considered for exhibition in the Metropolitan Art Show.
More works that met the traditional criteria for the Metropolitan Art Show were submitted by photographers than by sculptors or painters.
All the works submitted for the Metropolitan Art Show met the traditional criteria for the show.
others.target_option: Some of the photographs submitted for the Metropolitan Art Show did not meet the traditional criteria for the show.

context: Leptin, a protein occurring naturally in the blood, appears to regulate how much fat the body carries by speeding up the metabolism and decreasing the appetite when the body has too much fat. Mice that do not naturally produce leptin have more fat than other mice, but lose fat rapidly when they are given leptin injections. Unfortunately, however, leptin cannot be used as a dietary supplement to control fat, since__.
question: What is the reason for why the fact that the mice that do not naturally produce leptin were from a specially bred strain of mice does not logically complete the passage?
answers: The mice who are producing their own leptin are not loosing weight until receiving the injected form.
Leptin is stated to occur naturally in the blood.
The underlying issue causing low levels of leptin could also be causing other symptoms as well, such as increased body fat.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following most logically completes the passage?
main_answers: mice whose bodies did produce leptin also lost some of their body fat when given leptin injections
the mice that do not naturally produce leptin were from a specially bred strain of mice
the digestive system breaks down proteins before they can enter the bloodstream
people with unusually low levels of leptin in their blood tend to have a high percentage of body fat
others.target_option: the mice that do not naturally produce leptin were from a specially bred strain of mice

context: It is highly likely that Claudette is a classical pianist. Like most classical pianists, Claudette recognizes many of Clara Schumann' s works. The vast majority of people who are not classical pianists do not. In fact, many people who are not classical pianists have not even heard of Clara Schumann.
question: Why is the reasoning in the argument not considered to be invalid due to its reliance on the ambiguity of the term "classical"?
answers: No presumption is made about classical pianists' ability to play any instrument other than the piano.
People who have not heard of Clara Schumann are logically not capable of recognising work as belonging to her; such an assumption would justify itself.

If most of the people who recognise Clara Schumann's works are not classical pianists, then the assumption that Claudette is a classical pianists based on nothing other than her ability to recognise those works is greatly undermined.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The reasoning in the argument above is flawed in that it
main_answers: presumes, without providing justification, that people who have not heard of Clara Schumann do not recognize her works
presumes, without providing justification, that classical pianists cannot also play other musical instruments
relies for its plausibility on the vagueness of the term "classical"
ignores the possibility that the majority of people who recognize many of Clara Schumann's works are not classical pianists
others.target_option: relies for its plausibility on the vagueness of the term "classical"

context: The level of sulfur dioxide in the atmosphere is slightly higher than it was ten years ago. This increase is troubling because ten years ago the Interior Ministry imposed new, stricter regulations on emissions from coal-burning power plants. If these regulations had been followed, then the level of sulfur dioxide in the atmosphere would have decreased.
question: Explain why it is not valid to infer that government regulations will never reduce the level of sulfur dioxide in the atmosphere from the statements above?
answers: Any planetary body with a solid surface whose surface is not renewed for millions of years becomes heavily pockmarked by meteorite craters and the renewal happens by volcanic action from enough heat produced within the core. If Europa has solid icy surfaces with very few meteorite craters, it would seem as though Europa has a core that generates enough heat to cause volcanic action.
The assumption is that coal burning power plants are one cause not the only cause.
Only Europa is discussed and the claims made do not indicate that the other moons are heavily pockmarked or similar to Europa.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following can be properly inferred from the statements above?
main_answers: If current regulations on emissions from coal-burning power plants are not followed from now on, then the level of sulfur dioxide in the atmosphere will continue to increase.
There have been violations of the regulations on emissions from coal-burning power plants that were imposed ten years ago.
Government regulations will never reduce the level of sulfur dioxide in the atmosphere.
Emissions from coal-burning power plants are one of the main sources of air pollution.
others.target_option: Government regulations will never reduce the level of sulfur dioxide in the atmosphere.

context: Community activist: If Morganville wants to keep its central shopping district healthy, it should prevent the opening of a huge SaveAll discount department store on the outskirts of Morganville. Records from other small towns show that whenever SaveAll has opened a store outside the central shopping district of a small town, within five years the town has experienced the bankruptcies of more than a quarter of the stores in the shopping district.
question: Why is the answer to the question of whether newly opened SaveAll stores ever lose money during their first five years of operation not useful for evaluating the community activist's reasoning?
answers: Whether there has been any successful campaign or not is not strong evidence that SaveAll may pose a threat to the town's smaller stores.
If a large proportion of the stores have closed down, it will bolster the activist's reasoning. If only a small proportion of the stores closed down, it will hurt his/her reasoning.
Whether Morganville residents do all their shopping in Morganville or elsewhere does not help answer the question whether SaveAll hurts its smaller businesses.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The answer to which of the following would be most useful for evaluating the community activist's reasoning?
main_answers: In towns with healthy central shopping districts, what proportion of the stores in those districts suffer bankruptcy during a typical five-year period?
Have community activists in other towns successfully campaigned against the opening of a SaveAll store on the outskirts of their towns?
Do newly opened SaveAll stores ever lose money during their first five years of operation?
Do a large percentage of the residents of Morganville currently do almost all of their shopping at stores in Morganville?
others.target_option: Do newly opened SaveAll stores ever lose money during their first five years of operation?

context: This year a flood devastated a small river town. Hollyville, also a river town, responded with an outpouring of aid in which a majority of its residents participated, a proportion that far surpassed that of a few years ago when Hollyville sent aid to victims of a highly publicized earthquake. This year' s circumstances were a reversal of last year' s, when Hollyville itself was the scene of a deadly tornado and so the recipient rather than the supplier of emergency aid.
question: Explain why the situation described does not closely conform to the generalization that people are more likely to aid those who have experienced a hardship similar to one they themselves have experienced than to aid those who have experienced a dissimilar hardship.
answers: Government relief programs are not mentioned at all by the passage
The support offered by Hollyville increased after they themselves needed assistance.
There is nothing in the passage indicating the people of Jollyville knew the people they helped before or the people that are helping them now.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The situation described above most closely conforms to which one of the following generalizations?
main_answers: People are more likely to aid people they know than they are to aid strangers.
Once a disaster has struck them, people are more likely to aid others in need than they were before the disaster.
People are more likely to aid those who have experienced a hardship similar to one they themselves have experienced than to aid those who have experienced a dissimilar hardship.
Those who have received aid are more likely to be in favor of government relief programs than are those who have not.
others.target_option: People are more likely to aid those who have experienced a hardship similar to one they themselves have experienced than to aid those who have experienced a dissimilar hardship.

context: Lines can be parallel in a Euclidean system of geometry. But the non-Euclidean system of geometry that has the most empirical verification is regarded by several prominent physicists as correctly describing the universe we inhabit. If these physicists are right, in our universe there are no parallel lines.
question: What is the basis for not requiring the assumption that the universe is correctly described by the non-Euclidean system of geometry that has the most empirical verification if prominent physicists maintain that it is in order for the argument to be valid?
answers: The passage doesn't state that non-Euclidean geometry does not have any parallel lines but it must be assumed to reach the conclusion that there are no parallel lines in our universe if those prominent physicists are correct.
The physicists who doubt the view are not important to the assumption.

The passage only states several physicists regard the view as correct , but it does not state most or does it need to be assumed because only the view of the several prominent physicists is being offered.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption that is required by the argument?
main_answers: Only physicists who are not prominent doubt the view that the universe is correctly described by the non-Euclidean system of geometry that has the most empirical verification.
Most physicists have not doubted the view that the universe is correctly described by the non-Euclidean system of geometry that has the most empirical verification.
There are no parallel lines in the non- Euclidean system of geometry that has the most empirical verification.
The universe is correctly described by the non- Euclidean system of geometry that has the most empirical verification if prominent physicists maintain that it is.
others.target_option: The universe is correctly described by the non- Euclidean system of geometry that has the most empirical verification if prominent physicists maintain that it is.

context: Readers give more credibility and respond more positively to negative restaurant reviews if the critics begin their reviews by discussing the things they enjoyed about the restaurant. Studies show that readers enjoy hearing positive comments before being told unpleasant details. Ttherefore, any restaurant critic should make sure to start every review by giving ample praise about the positive aspects of the restaurant before launching into any negative commentary.
question: What is the reason for not considering that people usually decide which restaurants to patronize based on the negative comments made by restaurant critics to be a factor that seriously casts doubt on the wisdom of the recommendation?
answers: Whether or not the medical procedure carries a high risk or not is not relevant if the patient still dies as a result of the procedure.
this argument strengthens the argument instead of casting doubt on it
this article has nothing to say about whether the critics are actually competent cooks
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously casts doubt on the wisdom of this recommendation?
main_answers: People usually decide which restaurants to patronize based on the negative comments made by restaurant critics.
Most restaurant critics do not have any official culinary training or formal training in the food industry.
Restaurant critics often receive bribes from restaurants to write positive reviews.
Newspapers and magazines will often only publish the beginning of a restaurant review to save space.
others.target_option: People usually decide which restaurants to patronize based on the negative comments made by restaurant critics.

context: Commentator: In many countries the influence of fringe movements is increasing. The great centrifugal engine of modern culture turns faster and faster, spinning off fashions, ideologies, religions, artistic movements, economic theories, cults, and dogmas in fabulous profusion. Hence, modern culture threatens the national identities that now exist in the world.
question: Explain why the fact that new national identities are often forged out of conflicts among diverse groups does not weaken the commentator's argument?
answers: The preference for pluralistic or monolithic national cultures do not change whether or not those monolithic national cultures are being threatened.
If the rate of cultural change will soon change drastically, it only supports the fact that more modern culture threatens the existing national identity.
If the idea that compositing a large number of subcultures creates a more stable national identity, then modern culture would be stabilizing current national identities instead.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following statements, if true, most seriously weakens the commentator's argument?
main_answers: New national identities are often forged out of conflicts among diverse groups.
It is preferable to have a pluralistic rather than a monolithic national culture.
The rate of cultural change in most countries will soon change drastically.
A stable national identity is typically a composite of a staggering number of subcultures.
others.target_option: New national identities are often forged out of conflicts among diverse groups.

context: In 1988, a significant percentage of seals in the Baltic Sea died from viral diseases; off the coast of Scotland, however, the death rate due to viral diseases was approximately half what it was for the Baltic seals. The Baltic seals had significantly higher levels of pollutants in their blood than did the Scottish seals. Since pollutants are known to impair marine mammals' ability to fight off viral infection, it is likely that the higher death rate among the Baltic seals was due to the higher levels of pollutants in their blood.
question: Why does the fact that the strain of virus that killed Scottish seals overwhelms impaired immune systems much more quickly than it does healthy immune systems not provide additional support for the argument?
answers: The fact the other mammals in the area also died from viral disease would indicate that there was a problem in the area.
The passage does not provide the age or health of the dead Baltic seals, so this option could be supportive or not.
The passage doesn't claim that the pollutant each animal faced were the same or had the same effects.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, provides the most additional support for the argument?
main_answers: The kinds of pollutants found in the Baltic Sea are significantly different from those that have been detected in the waters off the coast of Scotland.
The strain of virus that killed Scottish seals overwhelms impaired immune systems much more quickly than it does healthy immune systems.
The large majority of Scottish seals that died were either old or unhealthy animals.
Among marine mammals other than seals, the death rate due to viral diseases in 1988 was higher in the Baltic Sea than it was off the Scottish coast.
others.target_option: The strain of virus that killed Scottish seals overwhelms impaired immune systems much more quickly than it does healthy immune systems.

context: Parent 1: Ten years ago, children in communities like ours did not date until they were thirteen to fifteen years old. Now our nine to eleven year olds are dating. Obviously, children in communities like ours are becoming romantically interested in members of the opposite sex at an earlier age today than they did ten years ago. Parent 2: I disagree. Our nine to eleven year olds do not want to date, but they feel intense peer pressure to act grown up by dating.
question: Explain why Parent 2 does not refute a generalization about nine to eleven-year-old children by means of an exceptional case overlooked by Parent 1?
answers: Parent 2 gives his or her alternative explanation by stating that they believe children are dating at an early age due to peer pressure to act grown up rather than Parent 1's explanation that children are becoming romantically interested at a younger age.
Parent 2 offers no criticism of Parent 1's claim in the passage, rather respectfully offers an alternative explanation.
No assumptions are made in the passage concerning thirteen to fifteen year old children by Parent 2.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Parent 2, in responding to Parent 1, does which one of the following?
main_answers: criticizes Parent 1 as a proponent of a claim rather than criticizing the claim itself
refutes a generalization about nine to eleven- year-old children by means of an exceptional case overlooked by Parent 1
provides an alternative explanation for the changes in children's dating described by Parent 1
assumes that nine to eleven-year-old children are as interested in dating as thirteen to fifteen-year-old children
others.target_option: refutes a generalization about nine to eleven- year-old children by means of an exceptional case overlooked by Parent 1

context: Creating a database of all the plant species in the scientific record has proved to be no easy task. For centuries, botanists have been collecting and naming plants without realizing that many were in fact already named. And by using DNA analysis, botanists have shown that varieties of plants long thought to belong to the same species actually belong to different species.
question: Why is it not justified to reject the claim that a person who consults the scientific record looking under only one of a plant's names may miss available information about that plant on the basis of the statements above?
answers: Seeing as the passage is saying it is no easy feat and due to the issues addressed and how much work to correct said problems, it is very likely most of the duplicates and omissions among plant names in the scientific record have yet to be cleared up.
The amount of duplicates and omissions in other fields is not relevant to the passage, though it is very likely the same could be true for other fields.

If there were no methods for determining whether or not distinct plant species have been given distinct names, botanists would not be able to see that some plants previously thought to be the same species are not nor would they know there are those being named after having bene previously.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Of the following claims, which one can most justifiably be rejected on the basis of the statements above?
main_answers: Duplicates and omissions in the scientific record also occur in fields other than botany.
Botanists have no techniques for determining whether distinct plant species have been given distinct names.
A person who consults the scientific record looking under only one of a plant's names may miss available information about that plant.
Most of the duplicates and omissions among plant names in the scientific record have yet to be cleared up.
others.target_option: A person who consults the scientific record looking under only one of a plant's names may miss available information about that plant.

context: Whenever an artist endowed with both a high level of artistic skill and a high degree of creativity combines these two abilities in the process of creating an artwork, the resulting product is a great work of art. Moreover, no work of art can be great unless both of these elements are combined in its execution. Thus, great works of art are necessarily rare.
question: What is the reasoning behind the argument requiring the assumption that a high degree of creativity and a high level of artistic skill are seldom combined in the creation of a work of art?
answers: This assumption is not required because according to the passage, a high degree of creativity is also needed for a great work of art.
According to the statement, artistic skill and creativity is necessary for great works of art, but it is not knowable how many will be produced.
The passage states that these traits only mean that a work of art can be great , but not necessarily will be.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the argument?
main_answers: Not every artist possesses a high level of artistic skill.
An artist endowed with a high degree of creativity and a high level of artistic skill will necessarily produce great works of art.
A high degree of creativity and a high level of artistic skill are seldom combined in the creation of a work of art.
Anyone endowed with both a high level of artistic skill and a high degree of creativity will produce only a few great works of art.
others.target_option: A high degree of creativity and a high level of artistic skill are seldom combined in the creation of a work of art.

context: On the whole, scientists do their most creative work before age forty, a tendency that has been taken to show that aging carries with it a loss of creative capacity. An alternative explanation is that by age forty most scientists have worked in their field for fifteen or more years and that by then they have exhausted the opportunity for creative work in that field. Supporting this explanation is the finding that __.
question: What is the reasoning behind the claim that a disproportionately large number of the scientists who produce highly creative work beyond age forty entered their field at an older age than is common logically completing the passage?
answers: There's nothing to suggest a correlation between a scientist's own expectations for their work and the reality of their opportunities for creativity.

Receiving a research grant is not necessarily an indicator that the scientist has been doing more creative work; in fact age could be an advantage due to having more tenure in the scientific community.
Whether older scientists find more satisfaction in other pursuits or not doesn't support an explanation about how many opportunities they have for creative work.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following most logically completes the passage?
main_answers: a disproportionately large number of the scientists who produce highly creative work beyond age forty entered their field at an older age than is common
the average age of recipients of scientific research grants is significantly greater than forty
many scientists temper their own expectations of what they can achieve in their research work by their belief that their creativity will decline as they age
scientists who are older than forty tend to find more satisfaction in other activities, such as teaching and mentoring, than they do in pursuing their own research
others.target_option: a disproportionately large number of the scientists who produce highly creative work beyond age forty entered their field at an older age than is common

context: A decade can be characterized just like an individual. Decades have specific character and unique quirks. They all start with a departure from the past decade and develop their personality throughout their timespans. Just as people in their twilight years start to look back on the events of their lives, people at decade' s end__.

answers: the argument focuses on reflections on the past, but with respect to a certain period and not the entirety of their past
the argument focuses on reflections on the past so this makes sense

Throw a big party.

context: Mel: The official salary for judges has always been too low to attract the best candidates to the job. The legislature' s move to raise the salary has done nothing to improve the situation, because it was coupled with a ban on receiving money for lectures and teaching engagements. Pat: No, the raise in salary really does improve the situation. Since very few judges teach or give lectures, the ban will have little or no negative effect.
question: Why is Pat's response to Mel not considered inadequate even though it denies Mel's claim without providing any evidence in support of that denial?
answers: No assumption is made regarding the ability of any current members of the judiciary being discussed.

As the motivation for the changes made was to improve recruitment of high quality judges, Pat should consider what effects the changes will have on such hypothetical future judges rather than their effect on current members of the judiciary.
Pat does not address the cause of the salary rise and lecturing ban, merely speculates as to their likely effects.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Pat's response to Mel is inadequate in that it
main_answers: simply denies Mel's claim without putting forward any evidence in support of that denial
assumes that changes that benefit the most able members of a group necessarily benefit all members of that group.
mistakenly takes the cause of a certain change to be an effect of that change
attempts to assess how a certain change will affect potential members of a group by providing evidence about its effect on the current members.
others.target_option: simply denies Mel's claim without putting forward any evidence in support of that denial

context: Cable TV stations have advantages that enable them to attract many more advertisers than broadcast networks attract. For example, cable stations are able to target particular audiences with 24-hour news, sports, or movies, whereas broadcast networks must offer a variety of programming. Cable can also offer lower advertising rates than any broadcast network can, because it is subsidized by viewers through subscriber fees. Additionally, many cable stations have expanded worldwide with multinational programming.
question: What evidence is needed to support the claim that some broadcast networks can be viewed in several countries, given that the statements above do not provide such support?
answers: This supports the main point of the passage because we are told that cable TV stations have expanded worldwide with multinational programming.
This supports the main point of the passage because providing 24-hour news programming is an advantage for cable TV stations over broadcast networks which must provide variety.
This supports the main point of the passage because we are told that cable TV stations are able to offer lower advertising costs than broadcast networks.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The statements above, if true, provide support for each of the following EXCEPT:
main_answers: The audiences that some advertisers prefer to target watch 24-hour news stations.
Low costs are often an important factor for advertisers in selecting a station or network on which to run a TV ad.
Some advertisers prefer to have the opportunity to address a worldwide audience.
Some broadcast networks can be viewed in several countries.
others.target_option: Some broadcast networks can be viewed in several countries.

context: Factory manager: One reason the automobile parts this factory produces are expensive is that our manufacturing equipment is outdated and inefficient. Our products would be more competitively priced if we were to refurbish the factory completely with new, more efficient equipment. Ttherefore, since to survive in today' s market we have to make our products more competitively priced, we must completely refurbish the factory in order to survive.
question: Why is the factory manager's argument considered flawed for shifting without justification from treating something as one way of achieving a goal to treating it as the only way of achieving that goal?
answers: the passage does give a cause for the problem as well as a solution, this does not make the argument flawed
the passage does give a definite recommendation so this suggestion is arguing with itself
this does not change the fact that the equipment is old and needs to be upgraded
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The reasoning in the factory manager's argument is flawed because this argument
main_answers: shifts without justification from treating something as one way of achieving a goal to treating it as the only way of achieving that goal
fails to recognize that the price of a particular commodity can change over time
recommends a solution to a problem without first considering any possible causes of that problem
fails to make a definite recommendation and instead merely suggests that some possible course of action might be effective
others.target_option: shifts without justification from treating something as one way of achieving a goal to treating it as the only way of achieving that goal

context: Hine' s emerald dragonflies are an endangered species that live in wetlands. The larvae of these dragonflies can survive only in the water, where they are subject to predation by several species including red devil crayfish. Surprisingly, the dragonfly populations are more likely to remain healthy in areas where red devil crayfish are present than in areas without red devil crayfish.
question: How does the fact that populations of red devil crayfish in a wetland do not drop significantly if the local population of Hine's emerald dragonflies dies out help to explain the surprising fact?
answers: The author assumes that the red devel crayfish are also relying on water to stay alive.  If the crayfish are finding ways t adapt to survive than this will benefit the dragonflies as well.
Even if one of the taller tables takes up less floor space, the restaurant's seating capacity is not changing as a result and so there would still be the same amount of diners.

If diners on stools do not stay in the restaurant after dinner as long as standard tables, then the restaurant would be able to serve more customers throughout the day as each would take a lesser amount of time.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to explain the surprising fact?
main_answers: Populations of red devil crayfish in a wetland do not drop significantly if the local population of Hine's emerald dragonflies dies out.
Red devil crayfish dig chambers that remain filled with water even when the surrounding wetlands dry up.
Red devil crayfish present no threat to adult Hine's emerald dragonflies.
The varied diet of the red devil crayfish does not include any animal species that prey on dragonfly larvae.
others.target_option: Populations of red devil crayfish in a wetland do not drop significantly if the local population of Hine's emerald dragonflies dies out.

context: After purchasing a pot-bellied pig at the pet store in Springfield, Amy was informed by a Springfield city official that she would not be allowed to keep the pig as a pet, since city codes classify pigs as livestock, and individuals may not keep livestock in Springfield.
question: Why does the city official's argument not depend on the assumption that any animal not classified as livestock may be kept in Springfield?
answers: the classification does not matter since the pig could be classified as livestock if individuals in Springfield were allowed to keep livestock in Springfield.
Pigs are the issue, not whether dogs and cats are considered pets or livestock.
If Amy did not live in Springfield, the laws of Springfield would not be applicable.

others.main_question: The city official's argument depends on assuming which one of the following?
main_answers: Pigs are not classified as pets in Springfield.
Any animal not classified as livestock may be kept in Springfield.
Amy lives in Springfield.
Dogs and cats are not classified as livestock in Springfield.
others.target_option: Any animal not classified as livestock may be kept in Springfield.

context: When feeding, aquatic birds known as phalaropes often spin rapidly on the water' s surface, pecking for food during each revolution. To execute these spins, phalaropes kick one leg harder than the other. This action creates upwelling currents. Because plankton on which phalaropes feed typically occurs in greater quantities well below the surface, it is hypothesized that by spinning phalaropes gain access to food that would otherwise be beyond their reach.
question: Explain why the fact that phalaropes sometimes spin when they are not feeding does not strongly support the hypothesis.
answers: This would show you that they need to spin to access the food, if they spun everytime they ate it would be hard to tell if the spinning was necessary for the far down food.
This passage has nothing to do with land, it is talking about the water
The direction that they spin does not matter in determining the reason for the spin.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, most strongly supports the hypothesis?
main_answers: Phalaropes rarely feed while on land.
Phalaropes do not usually spin when food is abundant at the surface.
Phalaropes sometimes spin when they are not feeding.
A given phalarope spins exclusively either to the right or to the left.
others.target_option: Phalaropes sometimes spin when they are not feeding.

context: Tanya is a lawyer. Nearly all lawyers dutifully represent their clients' best interests, but a few unethical ones charge exorbitant and fraudulent fees for services. Some lawyers become millionaires, while others work in the best interest of the public. However, all lawyers are bound by extensive ethical codes, which vary slightly by jurisdiction.
question: Why is it not necessary for Tanya to dutifully represent her clients' best interests in order for the statement to be true?
answers: There are both lawyers who work for the public and those who work for private clients mentioned.
According to the article, although the ethical codes vary by jurisdiction, all lawyers, which would include Tanya, are bound to some sort of ethical guidelines.
Only some of the lawyers mentioned charge steep prices for their services, and we don't know if Tanya is one of them.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: If the statements above are true, which one of the following must also be true?
main_answers: Tanya works for the public sector.
Tanya charges exorbitant fees for her services.

Tanya is bound by extensive ethical codes.

context: Advertisers are often criticized for their unscrupulous manipulation of people' s tastes and wants. There is evidence, however, that some advertisers are motivated by moral as well as financial considerations. A particular publication decided to change its image from being a family newspaper to concentrating on sex and violence, thus appealing to a different readership. Some advertisers withdrew their advertisements from the publication, and this must have been because they morally disapproved of publishing salacious material.
question: Explain why the fact that people who generally read family newspapers are not likely to buy newspapers that concentrate on sex and violence does not strengthen the argument.
answers: The length of time the Dvorak keyboard takes to learn is not indicated in the passage and really has nothing to do with the success and beneficial factors in entails.
Some advertisers switching to the changed publication doesn't preclude other advertisers from withdrawing.

This would go against the claim that the Dvorak keyboard would be beneficial because it informs the reader of the passage that those who have been informed of the benefits of the Dvorak keyboard continue to use the QWERTY keyboard.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, would most strengthen the argument?
main_answers: Some advertisers switched from family newspapers to advertise in the changed publication.
People who generally read family newspapers are not likely to buy newspapers that concentrate on sex and violence.
It was expected that the changed publication would appeal principally to those in a different income group.

others.target_option: People who generally read family newspapers are not likely to buy newspapers that concentrate on sex and violence.

context: When students receive negative criticism generated by computer programs, they are less likely to respond positively than when the critic is a human. Since the acceptance of criticism requires that one respond positively to it, students are more likely to learn from criticism by humans than from criticism by computers.
question: What is the reasoning that the argument does not depend on the assumption that criticism generated by computers is likely to be no more or less favorable than that produced by human critics in response to the same work?
answers: The passage does not argue that students can tell whether a human graded them or not.
The passage does not indicate that compassion matters for accepting critic.
The passage provides not support for the idea that people are more likely to learn from criticism they accept.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends?
main_answers: Unlike human critics, computers are incapable of showing compassion.
Students always know whether their critics are computers or humans.
Criticism generated by computers is likely to be no more or less favorable than that produced by human critics in response to the same work.
Students are more likely to learn from criticism that they accept than from criticism they do not accept.
others.target_option: Criticism generated by computers is likely to be no more or less favorable than that produced by human critics in response to the same work.

context: A mosquito bite can transmit to a person the parasite that causes malaria, and the use of mosquito nets over children' s beds can significantly reduce the incidence of malarial infection for children in areas where malaria is common. Yet public health officials are reluctant to recommend the use of mosquito nets over children' s beds in such areas.
question: What is the basis for the public health officials' reluctance not being supported by the fact that the pesticides that are most effective against mosquitoes in regions where malaria is common have significant detrimental effects on human health?
answers: Mosquito nets that also protect against other insects is a reason to use them.
If no vaccines have been developed against malaria, officials would want measures such as nets to reduce the spread.
Children exposed to malaria creates an immunity which is safer in the long run.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, would provide the strongest grounds for the public health officials' reluctance?
main_answers: Early exposure to malaria increases the body's resistance to it and results in a lesser likelihood of severe life-threatening episodes of malaria.
Although there are vaccines available for many childhood diseases, no vaccine has been developed that is effective against malaria.
Mosquito nets provide protection from some insect pests other than mosquitoes.
The pesticides that are most effective against mosquitoes in regions where malaria is common have significant detrimental effects on human health.
others.target_option: The pesticides that are most effective against mosquitoes in regions where malaria is common have significant detrimental effects on human health.

context: United States hospitals have traditionally relied primarily on revenues from paying patients to offset losses from unreimbursed care. Almost all paying patients now rely on governmental or private health insurance to pay hospital bill. Recently, insurers have been strictly limiting what they pay hospitals for the care of insured patients to amounts at or below actual costs.
question: Why is it not valid to conclude that, if the hospitals reduce their costs in providing care, insurance companies will maintain the current level of reimbursement, thereby providing more funds for unreimbursed care based on the information given?
answers: Patients who cannot afford private insurance and do not qualify for governmental insurance fall into the category of unreimbursed care, which is something hospitals have always had to deal with.
Philanthropic donations may help to support a hospital, but they are not the main source of income and have not been the primary way for hospitals to offset unreimbursed care.
Since insurers are limiting payments to actual costs or less, there is no extra income to pay for losses from un-reimbursed care.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following conclusions is best supported by the information above?
main_answers: If hospitals do not find ways of raising additional Income for unreimbursed care, they must either deny some of that care or suffer losses if they give it.
Some patients have incomes too, high for eligibility for governmental health insurance but are unable to afford private insurance for hospital care.
Even though philanthropic donations have traditionally provided some support for the hospitals, such donations are at present declining.
If the hospitals reduce their costs in providing care, insurance companies will maintain the current level of reimbursement, thereby providing more funds for unreimbursed care.
others.target_option: If the hospitals reduce their costs in providing care, insurance companies will maintain the current level of reimbursement, thereby providing more funds for unreimbursed care.

context: A study of adults who suffer from migraine headaches revealed that a significant proportion of the study participants suffer from a complex syndrome characterized by a set of three symptoms. Those who suffer from the syndrome experienced excessive anxiety during early childhood. As adolescents, these people began experiencing migraine headaches. As these people approached the age of 20, they also began to experience recurring bouts of depression. Since this pattern is invariant, always with excessive anxiety at its beginning, it follows that excessive anxiety in childhood is one of the causes of migraine headaches and depression in later life.
question: What is the basis for criticizing the reasoning in the argument for failing to rule out the possibility that all of the characteristic symptoms of the syndrome have a common cause?
answers: The exact number of people who suffer from these symptoms is not relevant to the argument being made.
If the company pays each employee based on the amount of work and intensity of work, then Pauline would be justified in expecting higher compensation.
Whether Lorraine agrees with Pauline's newer wage or not is irrelevant to what she deserves.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The reasoning in the argument is vulnerable to criticism on which one of the following grounds?
main_answers: It fails to rule out the possibility that all of the characteristic symptoms of the syndrome have a common cause.
It does not specify the proportion of those in the general population who suffer from the syndrome.
It does not establish why the study of migraine sufferers was restricted to adult participants.
It makes a generalization that is inconsistent with the evidence.
others.target_option: It fails to rule out the possibility that all of the characteristic symptoms of the syndrome have a common cause.

context: A survey was recently conducted among ferry passengers on the North Sea. Among the results was this: more of those who had taken anti-seasickness medication before their trip reported symptoms of seasickness than those who had not taken such medication. It is clear, then, that despite claims by drug companies that clinical tests show the contrary, people would be better off not taking anti-seasickness medications.

answers: Most passengers experiencing seasickness should not result in a disproportionate number of people who took the medication reporting issues compared to those who didn't take the medication.
Both parties responding to the survey ensures a balanced finding which does not weaken or strengthen the conclusion.
Being tested by the drug companies' staff should not have any influence on the reported seasickness results.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following, if true, would most weaken the conclusion above?
main_answers: Given rough enough weather, most ferry passengers will have some symptoms of seasickness.
The seasickness symptoms of the people who took anti-seasickness medication would have been more severe had they not taken the medication.
The clinical tests reported by the drug companies were conducted by the drug companies' staffs.
People who do not take anti-seasickness medication are just as likely to respond to a survey on seasickness as people who do.
others.target_option: The seasickness symptoms of the people who took anti-seasickness medication would have been more severe had they not taken the medication.

context: The Ixazyiquo tribe are believed to be one of the few remaining tribes in the country of Malugiato to have never had any contact with the Lamandians, settlers who arrived in Malugiain during the last hundred years. Using satellite imagery, a team of anthropologists determined that the Ixazyiquo land is covered with thriving banana plantations. The anthropologists conclude that the Ixazyiquo tribe has in fact had direct contact with the Lamandians.
question: What is the basis for the fact that the Ixazyiquo being a hunter-gather society, which travel over vast areas of land to hunt, not supporting the anthropologists' conclusion?
answers: The shape of the Ixazyiquo banana plantations is irrelevant to whether Lamandians have had direct contact with the Ixazyiquo, since there is no information given about how contact between the Ixazyiquo and Lamandians would influence the shapes of banana plantations.

If only Lamandians know how to maintain banana plantations, the presence of thriving banana plantations on Ixazyiquo land means that either there are Lamandians on Ixazyiquo land or that the Lamandians have provided this knowledge to the Ixazyiquo, both of which imply direct contact.

The Wamalami having direct contact with both the Ixazyiquo and the Lamandians does not imply that the Ixazyiquo and Lamandians have had direct contact with each other, and this contact is irrelevant to the presence of banana plantations on Ixazyiquo land.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following, if true, would best support the anthropologists' conclusion?
main_answers: There is no standard shape to the Ixazyiquobanana plantations, which have taken on a form that best fits the soil conditions.
The Ixazyiquo are a hunter-gather society, which travel over vast areas of land to hunt.

The Ixazyiquo have had extensive contact with the Wamalami, who have had direct contact with the Lamandians.
