context: Movie Director: Movies come out the best, in terms of both critical and box office success, when a single person has full creative control over the final product. Studios providing "notes" to the director, writer, producer, or whomever controls that vision, stifle the creative process. Studio Head: At the end of the day, the film industry is a business. Movies will only be made if they are profitable. The most successful movies focus on subjects that the audience cares about, and the studios spend millions of dollars on test screenings to determine what audiences prefer. Whether the studio transmits its research by "notes" or informal discussion, the studio' s input must be considered.
question: What is the reason for concluding that the main point in dispute is that more than one person should be involved in the creative process?
answers: The debate is not over the method of communication but rather if that communication should occur at all or not.
Critical claim is not being debated but rather how a movie is received by general audiences.
The number of people involved is not in question but rather whether studio notes specifically have a negative impact on the success of a movie.
None of the above choices

others.main_question: Which one of the following best describes the main point in dispute?

Critical acclaim is more important than box office success.
More than one person should be involved in the creative process.

context: Seemingly inconsequential changes in sea temperature due to global warming eventually result in declines in fish and seabird populations. A rise of just two degrees prevents the vertical mixing of seawater from different strata. This restricts the availability of upwelling nutrients to phytoplankton. Since zooplankton, which feed upon phytoplankton, feed the rest of the food chain, the declines are inevitable.
question: Why does the statement that zooplankton feed upon phytoplankton not serve to support the idea that global warming poses a threat to all organisms in the argument?
answers: The relation between zooplankton and phytoplankton is not merely used to show that feeding habits change, but that these changes will have effects throughout the entire chain and will thus affect larger sea animals.
The relation between zooplankton and phytoplankton is not meant to argue whether or not global warming should be curtailed, but merely to illustrate the effects global warming will have.
The relation between zooplankton and phytoplankton is linked to how they feed the rest of the food chain, and thus how larger animals will be affected as they are part of that chain.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following most accurately describes the role played in the argument by the statement that zooplankton feed upon phytoplankton?
main_answers: It helps show how global temperature changes affect larger sea animals indirectly.
It is intended to provide an example of the ways in which the vertical mixing of seawater affects feeding habits.
It is offered in support of the idea that global warming poses a threat to all organisms.
It is offered as one reason that global warming must be curtailed.
others.target_option: It is offered in support of the idea that global warming poses a threat to all organisms.

context: Evolution does not always optimize survival of an organism. Male moose evolved giant antlers as a way of fighting other males for mates, giving those with the largest antlers an evolutionary advantage. But those antlers also make it harder to escape predators, since they can easily get tangled in trees. All male moose would be better off with antlers half the current size: they would all be less vulnerable to predators, and those with the largest antlers would maintain their relative advantage.
question: What is the basis for not considering the technique of disputing the relevance of an example thought to support an opposing view to be used in the argument?
answers: The text relies on counterexamples, not analogies.
The counterexample of the male moose is used to undercut the general claim.
The text relies on counterexamples, not contradictions.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following is a technique of reasoning used in the argument?
main_answers: disputing the relevance of an example thought to support an opposing view
undermining a claim by showing that it is self-contradictory
employing an analogy in order to dispute a generalization
challenging a general claim by presenting a counterexample
others.target_option: disputing the relevance of an example thought to support an opposing view

context: Human rights activists have urged consumers to be conscious of the labor practices employed by manufacturers, especially in developing nations, saying that if we accept moral responsibility for our impact on third world workers, we must buy products from manufacturers that do not take advantage of their workers. It is nearly impossible, however, to determine which manufacturers are employing fair labor practices. Because of this impossibility there can be no moral obligation to choose products in the way these activists urge, because__.
question: Explain why the principle that it is more important to identify the moral choice than to act does not provide the appropriate completion for the argument.
answers: There is no contradiction because the whole topic of the passage is agreeing with the fact that being at home is not synonymous with being in one's house.
The phrase "at home" is very clearly defined in the examples and not ambiguous.
If the morality of a product choice cannot be known, then it cannot be morally obligatory to choose one one product over another.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following principles provides the most appropriate completion for the argument?
main_answers: A moral choice is more important than a moral action.
The morally correct option is the one that maximizes a person's effort to do good.
It is more important to identify the moral choice than to act.

others.target_option: It is more important to identify the moral choice than to act.

context: PhishCo runs a number of farms in the arid province of Nufa, depending largely on irrigation. Now, as part of a plan to efficiently increase the farms' total production, it plans to drill down to an aquifer containing warm, slightly salty water that will be used to raise fish in ponds. The water from the ponds will later be used to supplement piped-in irrigation water for PhishCo's vegetable fields, and the ponds and accompanying vegetation should help reduce the heat in the area of the farms.
question: Why does the fact that the government of Nufa will help to arrange loan financing to partially cover the costs of drilling not strongly suggest that the plan, if implemented, would increase the overall efficiency of PhishCo's farms?
answers: Ponds on low-lying lands would make it harder to move the water to the fields, and they would prevent the farmers would have to replant the grain that was usually in that area.
Rather than having to buy and apply fertilizer, the farmers could rely on the fish pond to produce enough fertilizer that would be distributed across the fields at the same time as the water.
The potential for profit has no bearing on the efficiency of how the farm is run.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which of the following would, if true, most strongly suggest that the plan, if implemented, would increase the overall efficiency of PhishCo's farms?
main_answers: Organic waste from fish in the pond water will help to fertilize fields where it is used for irrigation.
Fish raised on PhishCo's farms are likely to be saleable in the nearest urban areas.
Ponds will be located on low-lying land now partially occupied by grain crops.
The government of Nufa will help to arrange loan financing to partially cover the costs of drilling.
others.target_option: The government of Nufa will help to arrange loan financing to partially cover the costs of drilling.

context: Some government economists view their home countries as immune to outside influence. But economies are always open systems; international trade significantly affects prices and wages. Just as physicists learned the shortcomings of a mechanics based on idealizations such as the postulation of perfectly frictionless bodies, government economists must look beyond national borders if their nations' economies are to prosper.
question: Why does the argument's conclusion follow logically if it is assumed that a national economy cannot prosper unless every significant influence on it has been examined by that nation's government economists?
answers: Economics and the physical sciences are different however this has no bearing on whether or not examining either study as a whole is of utmost importance.
If an annual water pollution level is added to previous years' levels, water pollution would get worse every year.
Air and soil pollution don't relate to the level of water pollution.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: The argument's conclusion follows logically if which one of the following is assumed?
main_answers: Some government economists have been ignoring the effects of international trade on prices and wages.
Economic theories relying on idealizations are generally less accurate than economic theories that do not rely on idealizations.
A national economy cannot prosper unless every significant influence on it has been examined by that nation's government economists.
Economics is weakly analogous to the physical sciences.
others.target_option: A national economy cannot prosper unless every significant influence on it has been examined by that nation's government economists.

context: A mass of "black water" containing noxious organic material swept through Laurel Bay last year. Some scientists believe that this event was a naturally occurring but infrequent phenomenon. The black water completely wiped out five species of coral in the bay, including mounds of coral that were more than two centuries old. Ttherefore, even if this black water phenomenon has struck the bay before, it did not reach last year' s intensity at any time in the past two centuries.
question: What is the reasoning for why the argument does not require the assumption that masses of black water such as that observed last summer come into the bay more frequently than just once every two centuries?
answers: The level of vulnerability of the coral, older or younger, may or may not fluctuate, comparatively.
Five species of coral have been discussed, although a global generalization for all coral in the bay, has not been asserted.
If the mounds of centuries-old coral were strong and healthy before the "black water" mass, they may very well be a connection to their destruction, after the "black water" mass recently.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following is an assumption required by the argument?
main_answers: Older specimens of coral in the bay were more vulnerable to damage from the influx of black water than were young specimens.
Every species of coral in the bay was seriously harmed by the mass of black water that swept in last year.
The mounds of centuries-old coral that were destroyed were not in especially fragile condition just before the black water swept in last year.
Masses of black water such as that observed last summer come into the bay more frequently than just once every two centuries.
others.target_option: Masses of black water such as that observed last summer come into the bay more frequently than just once every two centuries.

context: Geologist: A geological fault in the mountain under which the proposed nuclear waste storage facility would be buried could, after a few thousand years, cause the contents to seep out or water to seep in. Since nuclear waste remains dangerous for up to 25, 000 years, such seepage would be disastrous. So we should not place a nuclear waste storage facility under this mountain until scientists investigate whether this mountain has any geological faults.
question: Why does the fact that the scientists' investigation would increase dramatically the cost of storing nuclear waste under the mountain not strengthen the geologist's argumentation?
answers: The original usage is has no bearing on the argument of the article.
This means there is no doubt that their investigation would produce reliable and actionable results.
This weakens the author's argument, as the storage could be built and used and then abandoned/emptied (hopefully) prior to any seepage.
None of the above choices
label: D

others.main_question: Which one of the following arguments, if true, most strengthens the geologist's argumentation?
main_answers: The scientists' investigation would conclusively show whether or not the mountain has any geological faults.
Nuclear waste could be stored in the proposed facility on a temporary basis.
The proposed facility was not initially intended to be used for the storage of nuclear waste.
The scientists' investigation would increase dramatically the cost of storing nuclear waste under the mountain.
